column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/85573,2019,Designing Migration Policy Research,Engels,Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences,,['prof.dr. PWA Scholten'],,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

The thesis trajectory consists of two parts: ‘designing migration policy research’ and ‘thesis research’. During this course [designing migration policy research] the students learn about the design, methods and methodology of research on the border of public administration and migration students. Furthermore the students will develop their own research proposal and will learn to reflect and assess the formulation of a problem definition and research question; operationalisation of concepts into reliable and valid indicators; the selection of the appropriate methods of data collection and analysis and the formulation of a research design.

At the start of block 3, students will be matched with a supervisor, most likely one of the lecturers that taught the mandatory courses of the master program. This is coordinated by the GMD program directors and depends on the expertise and thesis-load of potential supervisors.

Students are only allowed to start with their actual thesis-research when their thesis proposal has been considered satisfactory by their supervisor. Once their proposal has been approved, students are allowed to conduct the research as detailed in their proposal, and report the findings of this research in their master thesis.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>In the process of writing the thesis proposal the student learns:

column2: • to independently provide an overview of the existent literature on the chosen research field;
• to independently apply public administration and migration theory to deduce hypotheses from, or to base qualitative expectations on, that will form the basis of the theoretical framework;
• to independently develop a clearly defined theoretical framework;
• to independently formulate and assess a theoretically and socially relevant problem definition and research question;
• to individually operationalize and assess concepts into reliable and valid indicators;
• to independently choose and assess the appropriate methods of data collection and analysis for the research design;
• to independently develop and assess a theoretically and methodologically profound and feasible research design for the research question formulated;
• to independently structure and reference a research proposal.

column2: <body>

column3: In dit vak maken de studenten kennis met sociaalwetenschappelijk onderzoek zoals dat wordt verricht door bestuurskundigen en sociologen. Ze leren hoe bestuurskundigen en sociologen op een wetenschappelijk verantwoorde wijze onderzoek kunnen doen om een bijdrage te leveren aan verbetering van de inrichting en het functioneren van de Nederlandse samenleving en het Nederlandse openbaar bestuur. Studenten maken kennis met de belangrijkste sociaalwetenschappelijke methoden: survey, experimenten, observatie, diepte interviews, inhoudsanalyse en analyse van bestaande gegevens.</body>

column2: <head>

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: <body>

column3: Na afloop van het vak is de student in staat:

column5: verschillende wetenschapsfilosofische opvattingen noemen en verschillen en overeenkomsten noemen;

de methodologische basisprincipes te beschrijven van de belangrijkste sociaalwetenschappelijke onderzoekstrategieën: survey, (quasi)experimenten en casestudies, inclusief de analyse van bestaande gegevens;
gebaseerd op een eigen onderzoeksvraag een afweging maken tussen verschillende strategieën;
een adequate probleemstelling (i.e. doelstelling en vraagstelling) formuleren;
uitleggen wat een theorie is en welke rol theorie speelt in verschillende wetenschapsfilosofische opvattingen;
uitleggen wat wordt verstaan onder ‘operationaliseren’ en voorstellen formuleren voor het operationaliseren van theoretische concepten;
sociaalwetenschappelijk onderzoek beoordelen op kwaliteit met betrekking tot de opzet, wijze van uitvoering en terugkoppeling;

de kennis van methodologische basisprincipes toe te passen door een probleemstelling uit te werken in een simpel en concreet onderzoeksontwerp, met de erbij behorende hypothesen, operationaliseringen en steekproefkaders.

column2: </body>

column1: In deze laatste module wordt er ten slotte van uitgegaan dat in theorieën over de economie - te beginnen met de theorie van het vrije marktdenken van Adam Smith - niet alleen een visie op de wijze waarop mensen zich tot elkaar verhouden (esse ad) maar ook altijd een mensbeeld geïmpliceerd is. Hierin zijn ook altijd drijfveren, deugden, ondeugden verdisconteerd en verwachtingen en behoeften gewaardeerd. Getracht wordt dit impliciete mensbeeld te ontwaren dat aan de in eerdere modules behandelde werken ten grondslag ligt. Inherent aan een mensbeeld is een opvatting over de menselijke waardigheid. Ook deze wordt aan de reeds behandelde werken onttrokken. De reeds bestudeerde werken zullen ten slotte ook bevraagd worden op hun impliciete opvatting over de menselijke waardigheid en de wijze waarop hier de bounded morality, bounded rationality en bounded willpower verdisconteerd is.

column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: Het verkrijgen van een antwoord op de vraag welk mensbeeld en welke opvatting over de menselijke waardigheid ten grondslag ligt aan de literatuur waarin de wisselwerking tussen deugden en markt, tussen de economische en ethische werkelijkheid tot thema is gemaakt.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/90377,2019,Developing Theory and Theoretical Contributions,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,"['dr. ON Solinger', 'prof.dr. JP Cornelissen']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>Theory and theory development are seen as crucial to making meaningful academic contributions to bodies of knowledge in management and organizational research. Despite its prominence, the processes through which we theorize are often left implicit, and not typically discussed or taught in doctoral training programs. The course tries to address this very point; participants will through a series of exercises, practical assignments and readings be trained in ‘reading’ theory in journal articles, and will also develop skills in the development of theory as part of their own research.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
1. To have a basic understanding of management and organizational theory; what theory is, and what its core components are.
2. To develop reflective skills in theory development; including basic argumentation and the formulation of propositions, construct clarity and persuasive writing.
3. To develop creative skills in developing theory through specific forms of reasoning such as conceptual blending and counter-factual reasoning.</body>

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: <body>

column3: This is an advanced course in development economics for master-level students in development studies with a particular focus on public policy. This ten lecture course starts with a discussion of the nature of development economics and the place of development economics within the broader field of development studies. Session 2 presents the main elements of classic and heterodox theories of economic development. Session 3 introduces students to the most prominent contemporary models of development and underdevelopment, in particular, endogenous growth theories, the debate about the ‘big push’ and the nature and causes of poverty traps. Session 4 shifts the analysis to the particular problem of agriculture. After highlighting the debate about the role of agriculture within economic development, the course will move to the analysis of the agricultural land market and show how market imperfections can lead to inefficient production decisions and thus hinder agricultural development. Session 5 analyses rural-urban interactions and discusses the nature of urban formal and informal labour markets. The focus will be on constraints faced by informal entrepreneurs and the policies that can be used to ease such constraints. Session 6 will discuss the role of population growth and fertility and show that demographic change has to be considered as endogenous to economic development and that policies that do not take this into account are likely to be unsuccessful. Session 7 deals with health and development. Again, it will be shown that the causality between both – health and development – is bi-directional and macroeconomic empirical evidence is mixed. Then the focus will shift to microeconomic studies examining the health-productivity relationship. Sessions 8 and 9 will discuss the policy implications issuing from the different theories in the context of real country problems. Empirical evidence in favour and against the various theories presented will feed the discussion. Session 10 will conclude the course. It should be noted that the course will also be sensitive to problems rooted in the inequality between men and women, such as for instance the implications of unequal access to land, financial capital, labour market opportunities or health services and policy measures that may be taken to bridge such inequalities.

column2: </body>
<head>

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: <body>

column3: After completion of the course, students should:

column5: Have knowledge about the most important mainstream and heterodox economic approaches to analyse the economic transformation of those countries known as the ‘developing world’.
Be able to identify the main hypotheses and processes explaining economic growth and development and how they relate to policy making.
Learn to identify market failures and to determine whether appropriate policies grounded in an understanding of these conditions can address such failures.
Critically assess the limitations and strengths of the theories presented and to understand the key points of discussion between alternative theories.
Relate economic theory and concepts to real-life situations and specific public policy contexts.

column2: </body>

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/96506,2019,Development Management and Reforms,Engels,International Institute of Social Studies (ISS),,['dr. JW de Wit', 'dr. S Tankha']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

This course is about the practice of development management as conducted by public sector institutions, development cooperation agencies and other related organizations. It also focuses on policy implementation and public sector reform, especially in the delivery of public services. It relates theories of policy making and implementation to the actual dynamics of implementation in often complex institutional contexts, characterized by weak or divided or indifferent institutions and governance systems, and where budgets, capacity and/or staff commitment are sometimes problematic.  Theories and empirical studies of state failure and inefficiencies are discussed and students learn about different reform strategies and tools, including administrative reform and shrinking the state. Students learn how organizations develop, maintain and change their dominant cultures, how they develop and lose competencies and responsibilities, and how they develop and execute strategies. They also learn key issues of how to manage reform and change, taking into account budgets, human resources and institutions. Different models and their relevance to developing/transitional country contexts are discussed in the course and students learn to distinguish types of implementation and their policy relevance. The course will accordingly also cover management skills such as in negotiation and leadership.

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>

column5: Understand the organizational structures of public sector institutions in relation to their objectives, and the crucial role played by them in administration and governance.

Understand the theories and practical dynamics of policy implementation through dynamic multi-stakeholder public processes that include public sector organizations interacting with many other societal actors.
Understand theories, strategies and tools of public sector and policy reform.
Acquire skills and tools for effective implementation in complex and often turbulent environments, relating to leadership, managing change, organizational analysis, negotiations, and public finance.

column2: </body>

column4: Wanneer een kind van 1 jaar begint te huilen wanneer zijn moeder uit zicht is, wordt dit bestempeld als normaal, leeftijdsadequaat gedrag. Wanneer een 5-jarig kind weigert naar school te gaan en alleen bij zijn ouders in bed wil slapen om maar zo dicht mogelijk bij zijn moeder te zijn, wordt het een heel ander verhaal… Wanneer maakt gedrag deel uit van ‘normale ontwikkeling’ en wanneer spreken we van ‘abnormaal gedrag’? Deze vraag is heel relevant voor psychologen in het werkveld van de klinische kinder- en jeugdpsychologie. In het tweede blok van de Master Klinische Kinder- en Jeugdpsychologie, zullen stoornissen die zich voordoen in de vroege kindertijd worden benaderd vanuit een ontwikkelingspsychologisch perspectief. Vanuit normale ontwikkeling en de ‘taken’ of uitdagingen die het kind daarbij tegenkomt, wordt gekeken naar deviaties in gedrag of emoties die op kunnen treden wanneer een kind deze ontwikkelingstaken niet goed doorloopt.
Het blok is een onderdeel van de eisen voor het behalen van de Basisaantekening Psychodiagnostiek van het Nederlands Instituut van Psychologen (NIP).

column2: </body>
<head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>

column3: Er is in dit blok veel aandacht voor ontwikkelingsprocessen en psychopathologie in voornamelijk de vroege kindertijd. Naast kennis over ontwikkelingstaken en daaraan gerelateerde stoornissen, vindt verdieping plaats t.a.v. specifieke populaties (bv. hechtingsproblemen bij kinderen van moeders met ernstige post-partum problematiek), omgevingsfactoren (bv. ouder-kind interactie bij peuters met een regulatiestoornis), of behandelingen (bv. gedragsmodificatie bij vroege voedingsproblemen).</body>

column2: <head>

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: <body>

column5: De ontwikkeling en verandering van psychologische functies vanaf de geboorte tot de adolescentie zijn onderwerp van dit blok. Hoe kan het dat een driejarig kind al in staat is redelijke gesprekjes te voeren en het verschil tussen mannen en vrouwen weet? Hoe slaagt een kind erin vanuit bijna niets zich te ontwikkelen tot een volwassene met een schat aan kennis en ervaring? Bestudeerd zal worden hoe kinderen leren spreken, denken, probleem oplossen en onthouden (de zogenaamde cognitieve ontwikkeling), waarbij oudere theorieën zoals die van Piaget afgezet worden tegen recentere ideeën. Daarnaast is taalverwerving een belangrijk onderwerp. Het is wonderlijk om te zien hoe een baby die als pasgeborene geen woord begrijpt en al helemaal niets kan zeggen, binnen twee tot drie jaar goed leert praten, zonder gebruik te maken van woordenboeken en syllabi vol grammaticale regels. Ook wordt er aandacht besteed aan de sociaal-emotionele ontwikkeling van het kind, zoals de hechtingsrelatie. Hoe raken baby’s gehecht aan hun opvoeders? Heeft die hechting invloed op onze latere ontwikkeling? Wanneer is een actieve puber gewoon druk en wanneer zeggen we dat hij een hyperactiviteitstoornis heeft?

column2: </body>
<title></title>

column1: This course will offer the students’ knowledge on the most important developmental changes that take place in life, particularly during childhood. More specifically, students will be expected to be able to do the following after completing the course:

column2: • A student should be able to: describe prenatal stages including relevant milestones/developments.
• A student should be able to: recognize and illustrate inheritance patterns.
• A student should be able to: explain the effect of teratogens on prenatal development.
• A student should be able to: reproduce a general timeline (approximate ages) of emotional, attachment, cognitive, language, moral, and gender development, particularly of milestones.
• A student should be able to: recall and illustrate common errors or mistakes which take place during the development of a domain.
• A student should be able to: distinguish and apply major theories within each domain, and outline major criticism on these theories.
• A student should be able to: identify external and internal influences on and consequences of developments within each domain.
• A student should be able to: recall and apply important measurement tools of observable elements of development.
• A student should be able to: identify sex differences.
• A student should be able to: recall start and finish of typical pubertal development, for both males and females.
• A student should be able to: identify internal and external influences on pubertal timing.
• A student should be able to: describe psychological effects of pubertal timing.
• A student should be able to: reproduce major brain developments in puberty.
• A student should be able to: identify and explain pubertal risk-behaviours.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/85707,2019,Developmental Psychology: From Infancy to Old Age,Engels,Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences,,['dr. HK Tabbers'],,Inhoud

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column5: Blok 2.7 gaat nader in belangrijke thema’s binnen de Ontwikkelings- & Onderwijspsychologie zoals nature versus nurture, continuïteit versus eindigheid en natuurlijke rijping versus actieve sturing. De verschillende facetten en fasen van de normale ontwikkeling van de kindertijd naar de (late) volwassenheid zullen worden bestudeerd. Immers, de ontwikkelingspsychologie beslaat niet alleen de vroegkinderlijke ontwikkeling maar ook de ontwikkeling van kind naar puber/adolescent en volwassene en zelfs de ontwikkelingen van de oudere mens. Ook de interactie tussen biologische determinanten van ontwikkeling en omgevingsdeterminanten zal worden belicht tijdens bijvoorbeeld de vroegkinderlijke ontwikkeling en de late volwassenheid. Aan de hand van problemen die in de onderwijsgroepen besproken worden en verdiepingscolleges zal inzicht verkregen worden in de wetenschappelijke stand van zaken betreffende fundamenteel en toegepast onderzoek en (empirische evidentie voor) theorieën binnen deze subdiscipline. Up to date kennis van dit vakgebied is tenslotte ook belangrijk om een geïnformeerde mening te vormen in maatschappelijke kwesties die vandaag de dag spelen zoals de effecten van kinderopvang op ontwikkeling, problemen tijdens de puberteit, ouders met een verstandelijke beperking etc.

column2: </body>

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>Kennis van Ontwikkelings - & Onderwijspsychologie is belangrijk voor al die sociaal wetenschappelijke professionals die beroepshalve te maken krijgen met kinderen en jeugdigen (in gezinnen, op school etc.) en een gedegen bijdrage willen leveren aan leer -en opvoedingspraktijken, zoals het begeleiden van (moeilijk) lerende kinderen en het uitbrengen van advies aan hun ouders en leerkrachten of om ernstig probleemgedrag te analyseren en een plan op te stellen voor een mogelijke, ethisch-verantwoorde interventie. Het doel van Blok 2.7 is het bieden van een verdere verdieping in de kinder- en jeugdpsychologie plus het geven van een algemene oriëntatie in de adolescentiepsychologie en de ontwikkeling naar volwassenheid en ouderdom. Specifiek wordt er van studenten verwacht dat ze na afloop van het blok: 1) een duidelijke beschrijving kunnen geven van de belangrijkste biologische, sociale en psychologische ontwikkelingen tijdens de kindertijd, adolescentie, volwassenheid en ouderdom; 2) een goed beeld hebben van biologische en omgevingsfactoren, en de interactie daartussen, die de ontwikkeling kunnen beïnvloeden; en 3) theorie, onderzoek en toepassingen kunnen evalueren op hun sterke en minder sterke punten.</body>

column1: Although development is an ongoing process throughout life, the focus of this course will be on the development of children. In this course, the main developmental theories (cognitive, emotional, social, moral) will be introduced.

You will also be confronted with different challenges that children all over the world experience while growing up. What role do media and technology play in the child’s development? What is the importance of cultural empowerment in explaining children’s development? What is the effect of child labour on children’s health and well-being?

The developmental theories and challenges will be debated in the context of three major themes in developmental psychology: nature vs. nurture, continuity vs. discontinuity, and universality vs. sociocultural context.
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/89920,2019,Deviance,Engels,Erasmus University College,,['dr. AS Leerkes', 'dr. R Kemmers']",,"Inhoud

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>

column3: Social order and social cohesion are unthinkable without formal and informal social norms. Conversely, a certain amount of deviance – forms of norm violation which are, to varying degrees, disapproved in society and tend to be subjected to punishment – can fulfil positive functions for social order and cohesion. This course focuses on five questions: (1) How are problems of deviance conceptualised in sociology and other scientific disciplines (criminology, psychology, natural sciences)? (2) How does the labelling of behaviour and identities as criminal differ across and within societies, and how can criminalisation processes be understood? (3) How can deviant behaviour be explained sociologically? (4) How do societies respond to deviance and what are the intended and unintended consequences of these responses? (5) How can deviance be studied empirically and what are the advantages and disadvantages of the available data sources and methods?

column2: </body>
<head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>

column3: After having completed this course, you are able to:

column5: explain the main similarities and differences between sociological, criminological and medical/psychological perspectives on deviance;
distinguish – and give examples of – different types of social norms
explain and apply theories about criminalisation;
explain and apply sociological explanations of deviant behaviour;
explain the complex relationship between social cohesion and deviance with a focus on neighbourhood social cohesion and neighbourhood crime;
explain how and why there is social inequality in punishment;
explain and apply sociological insights about the effects of punishment with a focus on imprisonment;
understand and explain the merits and limitations of the main data sources and research methods in the sociological study of deviance;
conduct a small empirical-theoretical study on a ‘deviance’ topic;

column2: </body>

column4: Pedagogen kunnen in hun latere werkveld op verschillende wijzen te maken krijgen met jeugdcriminaliteit. In dit blok wordt daarom aandacht besteed aan probleemgedrag en criminaliteit onder jongeren in een multiculturele stedelijke context. Er wordt ingegaan op een scala aan verklaringen voor probleemgedrag en criminaliteit (van sociaalpsychologisch tot sociologisch en criminologisch), strafrechtelijke reacties van de overheid op criminaliteit, het integrale veiligheidsbeleid en op thema’s waar jongeren in een multiculturele stedelijke context mee in aanraking kunnen komen zoals geweld, drugs, migratie en integratieproblematiek.

column2: </body>
<head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>

column4: Aan het einde van dit blok zijn studenten in staat om:

column5: de uiteenlopende verschijningsvormen van probleemgedrag en jeugdcriminaliteit in een multiculturele stedelijke context in relatie tot politieke, maatschappelijke en culturele ontwikkelingen te benoemen;
op basis van uiteenlopende sociaalwetenschappelijke theorieën het ontstaan en het voortduren van probleemgedrag en criminaliteit van jongeren te verklaren;
deze sociaalwetenschappelijke theorieën op een zinvolle wijze op actuele vraagstukken van jeugdcriminaliteit en probleemgedrag toe te passen;

mogelijkheden voor preventie, screening en interventies (en de effectiviteit) van het integraal veiligheidsbeleid ten aanzien van jeugdcriminaliteit te beschrijven en te begrijpen onder welke omstandigheden voor specifieke vormen van interventie wordt gekozen.

column2: </body>

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/85776,2019,Diagnostiek,Nederlands,Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences,,['dr. AP Ringoot', 'dr. R Kok']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

In dit blok wordt de complexe werkelijkheid van het diagnostisch proces geïllustreerd aan de hand van casuïstiek, waarin verschillende typen ontwikkelingsproblemen aan bod komen en er aandacht is voor de context waarin de problemen zijn ontstaan en waarin de diagnostiek moet plaatsvinden. Gecombineerd met het practicum waarin verschillende diagnostische instrumenten worden behandeld wordt het diagnostisch traject voor verschillende casussen doorlopen. Omdat de ontwikkeling van elk kind anders verloopt, dus ook bij kinderen met een ontwikkelingsprobleem, wordt van je verwacht dat je de vergaarde kennis van de afgelopen jaren, gecombineerd met de kennis die je in dit blok opdoet gedurende de werkgroepen, het practicum en de colleges, kunt combineren om zo tot onderkennende, verklarende en/of indicerende hypothesen te komen voor de specifieke kinderen. Het is namelijk van belang dat er geleerd wordt hoe een diagnose/hypothese tot stand komt zodat je na deze studie zelf in staat bent het volledige diagnostisch proces te doorlopen bij kinderen met ontwikkelingsproblematiek. Je moet daarom leren hoe je problematiek bij het kind in het kader van omgevingsinvloeden, culturele invloeden, genderverschillen en leeftijdskenmerken moet bezien en tot een afgewogen diagnose kan komen die kan leiden tot handelingsgerichte adviezen.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: • heb je kennis van  het proces van diagnostiek van kinderen, al dan niet met een verstandelijke beperking; het beloop van (lage) intelligentie door de jaren heen, comorbiditeit van gedragsproblemen, invloed van ouders en culturele diversiteit
(intended learning outcomes 1, 2, 3 en 4)

• heb je kennis van effecten van gender- en cultuurverschillen en kun je de diagnostiek en daarmee samenhangende opvoeding en problematiek van het betreffende kind benaderen vanuit de zienswijze van de ouder met bijbehorende culturele gedachten gangen
(intended learning outcomes 1, 2, 3 en 4)

• heb je kennis van het proces van diagnostiek bij jonge kinderen waarbij sprake is van psychopathologie; het belang van ontwikkelingsleeftijd, stabiliteit van diagnoses, meetinstrumenten, dynamisch testen en het kind in zijn (culturele) context
(intended learning outcomes 1, 2, 3 en 4)

• heb je kennis van de invloed van ouders met psychische problemen op het ontstaan van gedragsproblemen bij kinderen; op welke wijze kan dit in kaart worden gebracht en hoe kijken verschillende culturen tegen psychopathologie aan
(intended learning outcomes 1, 2, 3 en 4)
• kun je de verschillende fasen van de diagnostische cyclus in de praktijk doorlopen en keuzes die hierbij gemaakt worden kritisch beschouwen
(intended learning outcomes 3, 7-14)
• heb je kennis van ethische dilemma’s bij diagnostiek en leer je op basis van kennis en ethiek welke beslissingen juist (kunnen) zijn
(intended learning outcomes 2 en 3)

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/85739,2019,Diagnostische vaardigheden,Nederlands,Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences,,['dr. MHF Deutz'],,Inhoud

column2: <title></title>
<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />

column1: Dit practicum bouwt voort op eerdere Testvaardigheden (1.4, 1.5, 3.4) en Gespreksvaardigheden (1.6, 2.1) practica, waarin studenten basisvaardigheden hebben opgedaan met betrekking tot de afname, rapportage en terugkoppeling van een psychodiagnostisch onderzoek. In dit practicum maken studenten kennis met het diagnostische proces in de praktijk en zal er voortgebouwd worden op de reeds verworven vaardigheden.

column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: <div>Na afronding van dit practicum hebben studenten:

column2: • Kennis van en inzicht in het doorlopen van de verschillende stappen (intake tot en met advies) van de diagnostische cyclus (eindterm 3);

• Vaardigheden ontwikkeld voor het opstellen en toetsen van diagnostische hypothesen en het kunnen nemen van beslissingen ten aanzien van de te nemen stappen in een diagnostische procedure, rekening houdend met de verschillen tussen cliënten (i.e. gender, leeftijd, culturele diversiteit) (eindtermen 8, 9 en 10);
• Vaardigheden opgedaan om diagnostische middelen (observatie, interview) en instrumenten (tests, vragenlijsten) te herkennen, te selecteren, te scoren en te interpreteren (eindterm 9 en 13);

• Vaardigheden opgedaan om onderdelen van de diagnostische cyclus (klachtanalyse, probleemanalyse, diagnostisch perspectief, toetsing en diagnostische conclusie) te doorlopen en schriftelijk vast te leggen volgens de richtlijnen die gelden voor de NVO Basisaantekening Diagnostiek (eindtermen 7, 9 en 12);
• De student is in staat om kritisch te reflecteren op het eigen handelen en professioneel om te gaan met collega's, cliënten en hun systeem (eindtermen 7 en 14);
• De student is zich bewust van de ethische dilemma’s en het belang van een beroepscode tijdens het diagnostisch proces (eindtermen 7 en 12);
• De student leert hoe het is om te werken in een team (eindterm 11).

column1: De student is in staat om zonder instructie en met enige begeleiding (onderdeel schrijfonderwijs):

column2: • Een samenhangende en heldere testrapportage te schrijven;
• Een professionele schrijfstijl toe te passen en deze af te stemmen op een specifieke doelgroep (e.g. kinderen, ouders, leerkrachten en andere professionals);
• Een (gedeeltelijke) casusbeschrijving conform NVO-richtlijnen betreffende de Basisaantekening Diagnostiek te schrijven;
• Toetsbare hypothesen op te stellen en deze wetenschappelijk te onderbouwen.

column2: <title></title>
<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: For most of us, digital content is omnipresent in our lives: we consume it daily, but also produce it regularly. Posting a photo on Instagram, writing a review on Amazon, or reading the course description online: these are some everyday forms through which we engage with, consuming and producing, digital content.

In this course, we take a look behind the scenes of digital content. Students will analyze what role digital content plays in the field of media and communication. In eight weeks, students will explore and reflect upon practices like digital storytelling or digital marketing. This theoretical foundation equips students to apply their knowledge to analyze various case studies. Moreover, students will put these theoretical insights to the test by working on a digital content case for a particular target audience or stakeholder

column2: <title></title>
<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>
• The key developments and trends in and of digital content as a communication practice
• Critical perspectives and theories on digital content, media ethics and media literacy
• The relevance of digital content in the field of media and communication
• The various strategies and roles digital content can take within the field of media and communication
• Apply relevant theoretical insights to analyze digital content
• Critically reflect on existing digital content, in both verbal and written form
• Design and create digital content for a particular audience or stakeholder(s)
• Work in international and intercultural teams to evaluate and ameliorate a digital content case

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/87163,2019,Digital Content and Creative Industries,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,['dr. D Castro Marino'],,"Inhoud

column2: <title></title>
<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: Digital media has transformed the way creators produce entertainment as well as redefine audience’s experiences. For example, YouTube, Facebook and Twitter, among other platforms, have been used by both professional and amateur creators to not only distribute new types of entertainment products, but to also offer a multi-screen experience to their audiences.

This research workshop will, thus, explore how digital media transforms the creative process of entertainment products (e.g. TV series, videogames) and audience’s experiences. The course is divided into two main sections. In the first one, students will engage in the reading and discussion of   a selected group of academic texts on the topic. In the second section of the course, students will design and carry out their own research project on digital media and entertainment.

As future communication experts, students need to both understand how digital media impacts both the creative process of entertainment products and the audience’s experiences. Furthermore, students will have the opportunity to put into practice (and further develop) their research skills, as well as reflect on their own media consumption practices. Finally, the workshop will offer the students a multimedia, interactive and collaborative learning environment to help them achieve the learning goals

column2: <title></title>
<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: <body>At the end of this research workshop, students will be able to:

column2: • Conduct an empirical qualitative research project
• Produce an academically sound research paper in collaboration with (international) peers
• Communicate their research findings through a poster presentation
• Evaluate the poster presentation of a peer following the criteria given in class

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/89872,2019,Digital Cultures & Information Wars: Algorithms, Memes & More",Engels,Erasmus University College,,"['CS Dwyer, MA', 'S Koevoets']",,"Inhoud

column2: <title></title>
<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: Since the turn of the millennium the democratisation of information- and communication technologies and the proliferation of social media have significantly changed our social interactions and social structures, economies and businesses. This course analyses the digitalisation of everyday life by using case studies of large new media organisations (Google, Facebook, Twitter, Wikipedia, Uber, etc.) structured around themes such as algorithms, filter bubbles, troll farms, meme cultures, 4chan, the platform economy, information wars, and post-truth politics. It addresses these cases and themes from the perspective of Media Studies, Political Economy and Science and Technology Studies, three very influential critical traditions within the field of cultural analysis.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>After this course, students will be able to:

column2: • Describe and explain the various histories of the social media platforms and applications under discussion;
• Understand the basic tenets of the political economic and STS perspectives on Social Media;
• Critically evaluate the organizational ecologies and business models of the social media platforms and applications under discussion;
• Critically evaluate the ways in which social practices and social media interfaces are co-constituted;
• Formulate a personal standpoint concerning the debates about the ‘effects’ of social media in domains such as privacy, creativity, copyright, distraction, sharing and sociability.
• Write and present a conference research paper.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/87516,2019,Digital Decision Making,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,['prof.dr. M Weinmann -'],,"Inhoud

column2: <title></title>
<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />

</style>

column1: Many choices are made in digital environments, however, not only the sheer number of choices but also their presentation may influence our decisions and distort us, because we have only limited cognitive capacities to cope with lots of choices. In this course, we will focus on digital decisions, made in digital environments such as websites or apps, with emphasis on how these decisions deviate from rational and/or ethical standards. Understanding how digital environments influence our choices can help to improve our decision-making.</body>

column2: <title></title>
<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: As part of this course, students will learn how websites influence our choices and how we can improve digital decision-making. Through practical, hands-on assignments, we will discuss:

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/87509,2019,Digital Footprints of Consumer Preferences,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,['dr. A Martinovici'],,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Consumers use various technologies in their everyday life, such as mobile applications, internet browsers, social networks, and wearables. In doing so, consumers leave a digital footprint - a stream of data that describes their online activities. Sometimes, they explicitly share content with other people (e.g. social networks, forums) or have a direct communication with a company (e.g. online customer service). Data that consumers intentionally submit online is defined as active digital footprint. At the same time, consumers also leave a passive digital footprint: their search history, the news they read online, or the location and time when they use a device. Both active and passive digital footprints can reveal consumer attitudes, interests, and preferences. This brings numerous opportunities and challenges for companies, consumers, and public policy makers.

This course discusses the benefits and risks associated with the use of digital footprints for marketeers, consumers, and policy makers. Brand managers can use detailed consumer level data to gain better insights about their target group and to adapt their communication and branding strategies accordingly. At the same time, consumers and policy makers are becoming more concerned about how digital footprints are collected and used. This course will help you develop an in-depth understanding of potential ethical issues related to digital footprints and measures that can mitigate such risks (e.g. the EU General Data Protection Regulation).

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: • Understand and explain the importance of digital footprints for consumers, policy, and businesses.
• Identify strengths and weaknesses in how companies handle consumer data.
• Recognize potential ethical issues related to digital footprints.
• Understand and explain implications of the GDPR for the EU marketplace.
• Provide managerial and policy recommendations.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/87456,2019,Digital Marketing Strategy,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,['dr. X Chen'],,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

The development of practice and research in marketing is always accompanied by advancement in technologies. From 1921 when Queensboro Corporation paid for the first radio commercial to 2015 when Oreo used “#RedVelvetOreo” to promote its new cookie flavor on Twitter, technologies have exerted profound influence on how marketers connect with consumers. The technological advancements bring forth new opportunities while posing unprecedented challenges for marketers. This course balances the strategy and tactic side of digital marketing by not only examining how to develop digital marketing strategies to increase shareholder value and sustain competitive advantage but also creating hands-on experiences with different digital marketing tools. With a systematic approach, we will explore various managerial problems such as how to design a website and drive traffic, how to optimize search engine efforts, how to purchase inventory for online display advertising, and how to allocate budget to different online communication channels. With these discussion, this course aims to shape your perspective as a digital marketing leader.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: <li>
Understand how digital marketing strategies fit with overall marketing and/or media strategy;
<li>
Learn to formulate and implement a digital marketing strategy, calculate digital marketing effort and ROI;
<li>
Understand the major digital marketing tools: web development and analytics, search engine marketing, mobile marketing and email marketing;
<li>
Learn how to perform web analytics, carry out keywords bidding, and purchase inventory for online display advertising.
<li>
To understand digital marketing landscape and marketing in ever-evolving digital age.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/87116,2019,Digital Media Analysis,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,"['dr. JS Lee', 'dr. M Tulin']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
It is often rightly noted that people have more and easier access to information than ever before, and that there is more media created today (often by media users and audiences) than at any point

in history. This vast and diverse media content offers an incredible opportunity, but also challenge, to media analysts. Some of the most difficult questions facing media research concern not only how to properly identify critically important media texts, but also how to collect and make sense of patterns that can be observed within and across media. Here, students will be provided scientific and industry-leading methodological tools in order to carry out these tasks, particularly in social media environments.

The human and computer-assisted approaches for digital media analysis blend qualitative and quantitative techniques. In conjunction with real-world and practical modules, this course opens doors for students to apply innovative and groundbreaking analytic techniques that can contribute to shaping the future directions of media research.
Note: The course will be cancelled if there are fewer than 10 students. The maximum number of participants is 25. IBCoM students take priority over other students.

column2: <title></title>

</style>
• Digital media analysis and their applicability in the field of media and communication.
• Research designs and measuring instruments for social media analysis.
• Practical considerations necessary for social media analysis, for example the concepts and issues surrounding the collection of online data and their management.

• Collect and analyze data from social media (Twitter, Facebook, YouTube), and news (LexisNexis) on topics of their choice.
• Present digital research in clear, novel and engaging ways, orally and in writing.
• Perform basic text analysis, topic modeling, sentiment analysis, and network analysis.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/90394,2019,Digital Media and Cultural Identities,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,['dr. G Evolvi'],,"Inhoud

column2: <title></title>
<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: Digital media are increasingly present in people’s everyday life. The proliferation of smartphones and Internet connections results in social interactions often based on digital communication, which modify and – sometimes – replace face-to-face discussions. This has an impact on how individuals and communities frame and express their cultural identities. Therefore, identity becomes a frequently discussed topic on social media and other Internet venues, involving characteristics such as gender, sexuality, religion, political affiliation, (dis)ability, ethnicity and race. Digital spaces can both help people to affirm and diffuse cultural identities within mainstream culture, and become tools for discrimination and hate speech against certain identity groups. By exploring different digital media platforms –such as Twitter, Facebook, blogs, You Tube –this class will discuss how cultural identities change, evolve, and are negotiated on the Internet. Students will analyze international case studies connected to digital media and cultural identities, such as the #MeToo and #BlackLivesMatter campaigns, the diffusion of online Islamophobia and Anti-Semitism, and Internet narratives about LGBTQ+ rights and same-sex unions.

column2: <title></title>
<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>
• How current academic perspectives on digital media allow exploring people' online self‐representations
• How the articulation of cultural identities affects and impacts digital media use in contemporary societies
• How the current proliferation of digital media offers new venues for both affirming and marginalizing identity groups
• Critically reflect upon the role of media in relation to cultural identities, analyzing both its positive and negative representations
• Independently relate the academic concepts covered in the course to novel examples within today’s digital media landscape
• Apply academic theories to case studies that illustrate the development and negotiation of cultural identities online

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/87175,2019,Digital Research Methods,Engels,"Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,"['D Kourelis', 'dr. JS Lee', 'dr. L Zheng']",,"Inhoud

column2: <title></title>
<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: This is a course that requires basic familiarity with qualitative and quantitative social sciences research methods. Technical proficiency in any particular digital analysis method or tool is not a prerequisite. However, a willingness to experiment with digital technologies that, due to their novelty, will not always work as expected is necessary to succeed in the course. Most business research happens in teams, so this course will include a group research project in addition to individual work. After completion of this course, students will be able to gather and analyze digital data for future projects using appropriate methodologies and tools.

The course provides an introduction into the different aspects of researching the digital. It is not exhaustive; comprehensive coverage of the material would require multiple courses. Instead, students will acquire a feel for methods and tools of research as well as where to look for them in the digital world. This is crucial within the program of media and communication, where in other courses as well as in the thesis, students have to be able to choose and use different tools and methods in their own research.

Via lectures and interactive hands-on workshops, students will become acquainted with theoretical concepts and scholarly debates surrounding digital research methods combined with a hands-on approach of dealing with data. Bringing in topics such as information visualization and design also sheds light on other important aspects of research: how and in what form to communicate outcomes?

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/90393,2019,Digital media and health communication,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,['dr. DC Ramos Antunes da Silva'],,"Inhoud

column2: <title></title>
<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: As digital media become ubiquitous, they affect how we circulate information about health. The changes are multi-folded: (1) organisations are now more connected to their clients and, then, have to provide accessible venues for communication; (2) patients are not only connected to organisations, but also to each other, circulating information and creating narratives without the need of a mediator; and (3) the hyperconnected society provides different social constructions that shape health communication. These digital practices concern citizens and researchers interested in the health arena, as well as professionals in the field of communication who aspire to work for healthcare industries. Those in the field have now to understand the impacts of digital media on how they will posit themselves and produce discourse, mainly by adapting to a society that is actively exchanging health information online.

column2: <title></title>

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/87208,2019,Digitalisering en Netwerksamenleving,Nederlands,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,['dr. PC Ruigrok'],,"Inhoud

column1: Het mediagebruik van Nederlanders is aan het veranderen en dit betekent ook dat ze op andere manieren nieuws tot zich nemen. Dit heeft grote gevolgen voor de journalistiek. Processen van commercialisering en popularisering, maar ook nieuwe technieken, e-technologie en de permanente mogelijkheid via ‘mobile devices’ media-uitingen te volgen en daar interactief aan deel te nemen, hebben de (politieke) informatievoorziening – en daarmee ook de opiniestructuur – drastisch gewijzigd. Door sociale media loopt de interactie tussen mensen online en offline steeds meer door elkaar heen en begint die grens te vervagen. Die veranderingen gaan niet bij iedereen even snel. Er is duidelijk sprake van voorlopers en volgers en de vraag is hoe die verschillen te verklaren zijn en wat de gevolgen zijn van verschillen in digitale vaardigheden en online levensstijlen. Wat verandert er in de levens van burgers ten aanzien van onder meer sociale contacten, vrijetijdsbesteding en cultuurparticipatie? In het seminar wordt veel empirisch onderzoek dat inzicht geeft in de Nederlandse situatie behandeld.

column2: <title></title>
<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />

</style>

column1: Je maakt kennis met veel nieuwe concepten en als sommige concepten je al bekend zijn uit vorige cursussen dan leer je je daar verder in te verdiepen, ze met elkaar te verbinden en bij complexere vragen toe te passen en eventueel te operationaliseren voor onderzoek.
Je ontwikkelt kennis van en inzicht in:

column2: • de belangrijkste theorieën rondom digital journalism en een netwerksamenleving;
• de relatie tussen theoretische (journalistieke) concepten en de dagelijkse nieuwspraktijk
• wetenschappelijk onderzoek over (aspecten van) digital journalism en de netwerksamenleving.
• Je leert (mondeling en schriftelijk) te reflecteren en een visie te ontwikkelen op de huidige ontwikkelingen binnen de journalistiek en de toekomst van de journalistiek.
• Je leert werken met (veel) data en dat om te zetten tot een interessant artikel voor een medium.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/86311,2019,Dilemmas of Modern Governance,Engels,Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences,,['prof.dr. EH Klijn'],,Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Many scholars identify a shift from government to governance. Governments find themselves in situations where they need to govern in horizontal relations and are more dependent on a wide array of non-profit and for-profit organizations to achieve their aims. Problem-solving takes place in complex networks of for- profit, non-profit and governmental organizations.

In this course we extensively look at what governance actually means and what the consequences are of this shift from government to governance. The course especially focuses on a number dilemmas related to the shift toward governance when governments try to solve complex social problems:

1.         Effective governance; How to achieve effective actions in complex governance networks. Effective governance networks require connectedness between actors, issues and arenas but it is not so easy to achieve as  confirmed by the now vast literature on governance. Governance processes are characterized by complexity and this makes it hard to achieve good results. It requires extensive network management and linking of various interests and values of the actors and thus good connective skills of managers.

2.         Democratic governance; Networks do have a strong horizontal character in which societal actors receive influence on important decisions. This character sometimes sharply conflicts with the classical representational institutions. How to deal with the tensions between representative democracy and elements of participative democracy in networks is an important governance dilemma. The course will address questions of democratic decision-making, in particular how it relates to governance networks;

3.            Accountable governance; how to handle the fact that in governance networks many actors are responsible and thus accountable. Is it true as some authors claim that networks blur existing accountability and not only ‘no one is in charge’ but also no ‘one is responsible’. And if not what accountability mechanisms are at place in networks?</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: • Knowledge of modern theories of governance that have emerged the last 15 years
• Ability to recognize assumptions and theoretical arguments in these theories and relate them to (wicked) policy problems
• Ability to critically reflect on the assumptions of governance theories
• Capability to analyze governance processes and wicked policy problems with these theories

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/89107,2019,Distribution Networks,Engels,"Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,['dr. R Kuik'],,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Great challenges, of both economic and technical nature, are posed on companies in producing and then delivering goods on demand, on the spot, right when and where customers demand them. Since production systems usually cannot follow the demand fluctuations in detail, distribution systems are required to bridge temporal and geographical gaps, and the gap in scale between production and consumption. The activities and decisions to be managed in such distribution systems are manifold and include distribution network design, the planning and managing of inventories deployed throughout the networks, linking sources and destinations through transportation, achieving coordination in channels, organizing information and forecasting demand, and setting and maintaining standards for customer service.

This course focuses on the analysis, planning, and organization of these activities. The analysis, planning, and organization of decisions and activities in distribution is a daunting task in its own right. The task is compounded by the dynamics in the business context such as globalization and the rapid proliferation of applications of information and communication technology. Contributions from several fields have shaped today’s vision on how to master the challenges of fulfilment of customer demand. This course takes an analytical perspective on how to organize for performance of distribution networks. It captures key factors in formal models, which it then analyzes, thereby uncovering important trade-offs and performance drivers in distribution networks.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

This course introduces the fundamental units of analysis and design of distribution networks. The course studies their relationships, and their translation into formal models as a contribution to the understanding of the essential choices and trade-offs underlying attaining achievements of distribution networks. The course focuses on the geographical and the temporal dimensions of distribution networks thereby

column2: <li>
providing students insight in key drivers of performance in distribution networks and their interrelationships,
<li>

having students gain experience in capturing and analyzing these interrelationships through formal models, implemented in spreadsheets and other analytical tools, thereby enhancing a student’s understanding of value and limitations of formal models as part of decision making tools,
<li>

making students train analytical thinking and rhetoric in discussions pertaining to issues of distribution networks, thereby fostering a student’s understanding of managerial levers for steering performance of distribution systems as part of supply chain management.

column1: This course discusses the situation of teachers and trainers in urban contexts, serving classrooms with students from a large variety of socioeconomic and ethnic/cultural backgrounds. Processes in the diverse classroom and training settings are considered from a social psychological perspective (micro), from a learning and instruction perspective (micro) and from a school improvement perspective (meso). The starting point of the course will be recent patterns of migration, the ever growing diversity (super-diversity) in urban areas related to equity issues.

In project 1 social psychological phenomena during learning such as the role of stereotypes, teacher expectations and intergroup contact theory will be studied. In project 2 the focus will be on instruction in diverse classrooms and training settings and the role of variation and differentiation. In project 3, psychological needs of students according to the self-determination theory and cultural responsive teaching will be studied. Finally, in project 4, innovations in the urban context and the role of teachers in school development will be the main topic.  </body>

column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: <body>At the end of this course you will be able to:

column2: • Describe, compare and critique the main theories on stereotypes, teacher expectations and intergroup contact in the diverse classroom and training settings.
• Describe, compare and critique the main theories on variation and differentiation in classrooms and training settings with students from diverse backgrounds.
• Describe, compare and critique the main theories on psychological needs in education and cultural response teaching and training.
• Describe and evaluate key factors of organizing schools for improvement in an urban setting.
• Apply evidence-based coaching techniques and qualitative research methods in a concrete setting

column1: Diversity comes in many shapes and forms and has become a key notion in societal and scholarly debates. In media studies questions on diversity are usually geared towards gender, race and sexuality, and more recently also towards age and disability. Not only how diversity is present in media products but also effects of (not-so)diverse media content on the audiences in general and society at large are topic of investigation and often form the core of heated debates. For example, while some consider Beyoncé and Lady Gaga as feminist role models and resisting the stereotype of white, heterosexual femininity, others vigorously argue that both Lady Gaga and Beyoncé re-emphasize this stereotype. In this seminar, the production, representation and consumption of diversity are explored. To do so, concepts such as ‘stereotype’ and ‘diversity’ are critically scrutinized for their meaning and value in relation to media. Gender, race and sexuality are understood  as intersectional - in relation to one another and interdependent. Last but not least, popular culture and advertising take a central place, as these highly visual media are thought to contribute most to contemporary society’s imaginations of diversity.

• Current questions and issues of diversity in popular culture and advertising.
• critically examine and evaluate diversity in contemporary popular culture and advertising;
• Formulate their thoughts and views on diversity in an academically sound research paper.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/87255,2019,Dood en letsel: voorkomen, vergoeden en vergelden",Nederlands,Erasmus School of Law,,"['mr. FM Ruitenbeek - Bart', 'mr. M de Groot', 'prof.mr. SD Lindenbergh']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Vanuit veel wetenschappen is het nodige te zeggen over de vraag wanneer dood en letsel voorkomen, vergoed of vergolden moet worden. In deze verbredende minor brengen we deze inzichten bijeen, laten verschillende (gast)docenten hun licht er over schijnen, brengen we studenten aan de praat over de multidisciplinariteit van het onderwerp en confronteren we elkaar met tal van dilemma’s.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>De student kan na afloop van dit vak:

column2: • De centrale begrippen, de systematiek en de grondslagen van het aansprakelijkheids- en schadevergoedingsrecht grondig beschrijven en analyseren

• Inzichten vanuit verschillende wetenschappen (rechtswetenschappen, rechtseconomie, rechtspsychologie en gezondheidswetenschappen) over het voorkomen, vergoeden en/of vergelden van dood en letsel beschrijven, analyseren en betrekken in zijn eigen oordeelsvorming over het recht en de verschillende dilemma’s die dood en letsel met zich brengen

• Inzichten uit de beroepspraktijk over het voorkomen, vergoeden en/of vergelden van dood en letsel beschrijven, analyseren en betrekken in zijn eigen oordeelsvorming over het recht en de verschillende dilemma’s die dood en letsel met zich brengen

column1: Wil je graag de Nederlandse taal leren maar heb je gedurende het jaar nooit tijd? Of vind je een 10-weekse cursus te lang? Dan is deze cursus wat voor jou! Tijdens de zomercursus Nederlands voor beginners leer je in 2 weken wat je anders in 10 weken leert.

Deze cursus bestaat uit tien dagelijkse bijeenkomsten van 3 uur. Het afsluitende examen vindt plaats op de laatste dag van de cursus. Aan het einde van de cursus is de stof van één cursusniveau behandeld.
Wat leer je tijdens de online cursus zomercursus Nederlands?

Tijdens deze cursus leer je de basis van de Nederlandse taal, waarbij de nadruk ligt op de vaardigheden lezen, luisteren, schrijven en spreken in een alledaagse context. Onderwerpen die aan bod komen zijn bijvoorbeeld:

column2: • uitspraak;
• jezelf voorstellen;
• begroeten en afscheid nemen van mensen;
• afspraak maken;
• praten over je familie;
• café, markt, restaurant en kledingzaak;
• grammatica;
• vocabulaire;
• de Nederlandse cultuur.
<title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: Aan het einde van de cursus beschik je over een bescheiden woordenschat zodat je in veelvoorkomende en alledaagse situaties kunt communiceren. Het eindniveau van de cursus is A1 volgens het Common European Framework of Reference (CEFR).

column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>
• Deze online cursus vindt plaats van maandag 3 t/m vrijdag 14 augustus van 9.30-11.00 uur en 11.45-13.15 uur via Zoom. Er is een pauze van 11.00-11.45 uur.
• Deze cursus is toegankelijk voor cursisten met een academische achtergrond (hbo/wo).
• De steuntaal van deze cursus is Engels. In de lessen wordt echter zoveel mogelijk Nederlands gesproken.
• Het cursusmateriaal is niet bij de cursusprijs inbegrepen. In de bevestigingsbrief die je ontvangt als de cursus doorgaat, informeren we je over de details.
• Van de deelnemers wordt verwacht dat zij naast de dagelijkse contacturen ongeveer drie uur per dag aan zelfstudie besteden.
• De groepen zijn klein: minimaal 10 en maximaal 14 deelnemers. Let op! Bij minder dan 10 inschrijvingen behoudt het LTC het recht om de cursus te annuleren.

• Aanwezigheid bij de lessen is niet verplicht, wel raadzaam. Let op! Tijdens de laatste les vindt er een mondelinge toets en een luistertoets plaats. Om voor de cursus te kunnen slagen, dien je dan aanwezig te zijn.

• Het examen vindt plaats op vrijdag 14 augustus  van 16.00-17.30 uur, hierin wordt de lees- en schrijfvaardigheid wordt getoetst. Met dyslexie kun je extra tijd krijgen voor dit examen. Vergeet niet om je dyslexieverklaring met je verzoek naar ltc@eur.nl te sturen.
• Je ontvangt een certificaat als je de cursus afsluit met een 'pass' voor alle vier de vaardigheden.
• Lees ook onze voorwaarden.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/88799,2019,Dutch History in a Globalizing World,Engels, Nederlands","Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,"['CSM Hull, PhD', 'dr. JW Schaap', 'dr. ME Hay', 'dr. Y van Hoef', 'HB Harmsen, MA', 'prof.dr. HAM Klemann']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>In this course, an overview is given of the Dutch history from the medieval period until the present time. Not just what is the specifically Dutch will be discussed, but also how Dutch history fits in a European and global context. During its history, and especially in the 19<sup>th</sup> and 20<sup>th</sup> century, the Netherlands has increasingly become a normal Western country. The early Dutch history – the time of the revolt and the Republic – is relevant because Dutch developments of the era had major cultural, economic and political influence on the rest of Europe and even the world. At the other hand, Dutch history of the nineteenth and twentieth century can be seen as an example for the way in which Western European countries, all with their own variations, developed into rich countries with a good social system and a high degree of individual freedom. At the same time it will become clear that these countries – and certainly a small country like the Netherlands – lost most of their global significance with the decolonization, the rapid economic growth elsewhere in the world, and the shift in the geographic distribution of the population.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>Students understand the broad outlines of the Dutch history from the medieval period in a European and global context. They can explain the 16<sup>th</sup> century Dutch Rebellion as a pluralistic struggle of various groups and interpret the Republic as a civil society. They understand the position of the Netherlands as a colonial power in the perspective of Western imperialism. They can also explain why and how in the 19<sup>th</sup> and 20<sup>th</sup> centuries the Netherlands developed into a normal, small western country with characteristic movements such like liberalism, democracy, secularization and multiculturalism.</body>

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/87953,2019,Dutch law and Dutch Legal Culture in a Comparative Perspective,Engels,Erasmus School of Law,,['dr. AJ de Roo', 'dr. RW Jagtenberg']",,"Inhoud

column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: The course introduces the participating students to the main characteristics of the Dutch legal system and its legal culture.

The focus of the course is twofold. First, the students are provided with an overview of the general principles of the core areas of Dutch law, i.e. constitutional law, administrative law, criminal law and private law. Second, the focus is on the background and context of the Dutch legal system, based on the assumption that a good understanding of a particular legal system includes an understanding of its legal culture. To achieve this, the course will address typical (legal) institutions and procedures, the court system, and the legislative procedure illustrated by inter alia court decisions (translated in English) and other relevant legal documents. In addition, the introduction of court annexed mediation will be discussed in light of the implementation of the European Mediation Directive and the pursuit of more efficient and better performing courts.

The general approach of the course is comparative by situating the Dutch legal system in its European context and relating it to other legal systems and legal cultures. By comparing a particular legal system, i.e. the Dutch legal system, with other legal systems its typical characteristics will become (more) evident.

column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: At the end of the course students will have a basic understanding of the origin and structure of the present Dutch legal system and the general principles underlying Dutch constitutional, administrative, criminal and private law.
In addition, they will be able to relate Dutch legal culture to European and other western legal cultures.</body>

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/86303,2019,Dynamiek in Complexe Systemen,Nederlands,Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences,,['dr. JA Joosse - Bil, MSc', 'dr. PK Marks']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

De huidige bestuurskundige praktijk wordt gekenmerkt door een confrontatie met vraagstukken die systemisch van aard zijn zoals fileproblematiek, klimaatverandering, veiligheid en stedelijke ontwikkeling. Deze issues vragen om interventies in een complex geheel van relaties tussen publieke en private partijen, sociale en fysieke infrastructuren en natuurlijke ecosystemen. In deze module analyseren we verschillende aspecten van systemen, zoals toeval, stabiliteit, en de relatie tussen de individu en het collectief. We maken daarbij gebruik van evolutionaire theorieën, communicatietheorieën, economische theorieën en gedragstheorieën.

De studenten bereiden de colleges voor door voorafgaand een position paper te schrijven over de leerstof van dat college. Tijdens het college wordt van de studenten gevraagd om hun positie te presenteren en te verdedigen. Door middel van discussie tussen studenten en docenten proberen we beter te begrijpen wat de theorie betekent en tegelijkertijd te ontdekken wat onze eigen veronderstellingen zijn. De position papers worden beoordeeld en maken deel uit van het eindcijfer.</body>
Na afloop van deze module kan de student:
• verschillende theoretische benaderingen van dynamiek in complexe systemen beschrijven;
• een analyse maken van complexe systemen en de verschillende fasen waarin deze systemen zich kunnen bevinden;
• met behulp van verschillende invalshoeken de dynamiek van complexe systemen verklaren;
• een kritische houding ten opzichte van verschillende theoretische ideeën ontwikkelen;
• reflecteren op de persoonlijke leercurve door een vergelijking te maken tussen de aannames en opvattingen aan het begin van de collegereeks en eindsituatie;

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/85855,2019,EFR-Involve Research Project,Engels,Erasmus School of Economics,,"['CL Relou, MSc', 'JH Kranenbarg', 'prof.dr. KEH Maas']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

The EFR Involve Consultancy project distinguishes itself from the other EFR's initiatives by its social and research focused approach. In the programme, twenty students apply their academic knowledge to practice and make a sustainable impact on communities that need it the most. This is done in partnership with an NGO or social enterprise and under the supervision of the course coordinator. Both sides will guide and assist the students in setting up their research.

This project consists of four months of desk research (April-July), 2 to 3 weeks of field research abroad (August) and a final presentation for the partner (September). Below are a couple of topics the students worked on the past years:

column2: • Clean drinking water in Cameroon
• Sustainable energy in Ghana
• Youth unemployment in Uganda
• A sustainable relation between nature and people in Kenya

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: • Learn to answer real business questions and to work for a partner
• Learn to apply academic knowledge in a business environment
• evelop team work skills
• Perform socially responsible research activities
<title></title>
