column1: Only ESE students are eligible to obtain the 1 ECTS credit.

Master students and students of Fiscal Economics are not able to obtain the ECTS credit. They are only able to do the subject extracurricularly. If a participant meets the required attendence, the participant will not only receive 1 ECTS but also an EFR/ESE Job Market Skills certificate. For more information, go to efr.n/education or send an email to pm.education@efr.nl.</body>

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/90856,2019,ERIM Research Clinic Finance,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,['prof.dr. DGJ Bongaerts'],,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

This course introduces the student to research methodologies, data and software in corporate finance, investments, market microstructure and asset pricing. We cover research data available at EUR and students familiarize themselves with efficient ways of processing large financial databases using SAS. Moreover, students will be trained in using LaTeX for text formatting papers that involve many equations. We also discuss how research questions and problems are formulated, how actual data and empirical methods are used to answer the research questions and how important assumptions are handled (e.g. robustness checks, sensitivity analysis). Another important aspect of the course is to get an idea of how an academic career looks like and how to anticipate on important decisions to be made.

As a second part of this course, students will be introduced to the research that is done within ERIM over all programmes. This is done by a series of two-hour seminars given by ERIM members and fellows. In each seminar, recent research is presented. Attendance of these seminars is obligatory.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: • Become familiar with state-of-the-art research methodology, data and software in finance.
• Obtain the ability to write a research proposal
• Get an overview of an academic career in Finance.
• Write a referee paper on a selected finance topic.
• To familiarize the student with the research done by top ERIM researchers (within and outside the F&A programme).

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/90852,2019,ERIM Research Clinic Logistics and Information Systems,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,[],,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

This course familiarizes the student with recent research methodology by investigating several influential research papers in the area. Emphasis is given to how research questions and problems are formulated, how conceptual frameworks and hypotheses are developed and how actual data and methods are used to answer the posed questions and to analyse the impact of important assumptions. Based on the acquired insights, students are expected to formulate their own research project and write a report about it.

As a second part of this course, students will be introduced to the research that is done within ERIM over all programmes. This is done by a series of seminars given by ERIM members and fellows. In each seminar, recent research is presented. Attendance of these seminars is obligatory.

The assignment (2 ECTS) involves a literature review, which can be used as a preparation or exercise for your Research Master Thesis (year 2). The learning objectives of the literature review assignment are:

column2: • To familiarize you with the research topics studied and methods adopted in a selected number of sub-fields within the LIS domain;
• To learn to systematically search, identify, select, analyse and compare academic publications;
• To be able to identify possible inconsistencies, controversies or gaps in existing scientific literature;

• To learn to define an intended contribution to the scientific literature, and to define relevant and feasible research questions and research methods in order to deliver such contribution. You are expected to work on this literature review assignment in parallel to the research clinic lectures.
• A proposed outline for your literature review (1-2 pages), including:
• Research theme/topic;
• Scope of your literature review (type of publications, which journals, what time period etc.);
• Method for identifying relevant publications;
• Outline of the structure of the final review paper.
• The final review paper itself.

column1: The length of this paper should be 5000-7000 words.

The outline should be submitted to the Track Coordinators (Wilco van den Heuvel), and depending on the topic, a reader will be assigned to you to provide feedback and grade your assignment (in most cases one of the four LIS lecturers from the Research Clinic lecture series). We strongly advise you to submit the outline within four weeks after the start of the lectures; the final paper should be submitted within four weeks after the end of the lectures.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
To introduce you to the frontiers of knowledge and of research in LIS and to enable to formulate and evaluate a research proposal.
A second goal is to familiarize the student with the research done by top ERIM researchers (within and outside the LIS programme).</body>

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/90855,2019,ERIM Research Clinic Strategy and Entrepreneurship,Engels, Nederlands","Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,[],,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

This course familiarizes students with recent research by investigating several influential articles in top journals in the area. A variety of topics are covered, including corporate development, entrepreneurship, international strategy, strategic change, and sustainable strategy. Emphasis is given to how research questions and problems are formulated, how conceptual frameworks and hypotheses are developed, and how actual data and methods are used to answer research questions and to analyse the impact of important explicit and implicit assumptions used. Based on the acquired insights, students are expected to formulate their own research project.

The second part of this course will introduce students to the research that is done within ERIM over all programmes. This is done by a series of two-hour seminars given by ERIM researchers on a variety of topics. In each seminar, recent research is presented and discussed, so as to train students to develop a constructively critical research mindset. Attendance of these seminars is obligatory.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
To introduce students to the frontiers of research in the fields of strategy and entrepreneurship and to establish a solid basis for formulating a sound research proposal.
A second goal is to familiarize students with top research performed by ERIM researchers.</body>

column1: <body>The course explores the present and future of the European Union. More specifically, the decision making processes in the European Union and negotiating techniques involved. Through interactive lectures and plenary sessions, students will enhance their negotiation skills. In order for the students to further understand how the actors in the Union work, there will be two study trips, one to the Port of Rotterdam, an active lobby organisation in the European arena and another to Brussels, where students will interview managers of the EU Public Affairs.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>The objectives of this module include theoretical understanding of the functioning of the present EU, understanding of the formal and informal rules on the European level, development of vision, experiencing the way of working in the European policymaking arena, training and improving the negotiating skills and insight and understanding of public affairs at the European level. The course also aims to contribute to the acquisition of the following general academic skills: the ability to independently analyze issues, the ability to critically examine books and research reports in scientific journals, the ability to write a review about a scientific book, and the ability to contribute one’s own insights in a clear and structured manner, both orally and in writing.</body>

column1: In het kader van het vak EU-douanerecht en accijnzen wordt op verdiepende wijze ingegaan op een geselecteerd aantal onderwerpen uit het wetgevingspakket van het Douane Wetboek van de Unie. Aan de orde zullen onder andere komen het formele douanerecht, (het ontstaan van) de douaneschuld (classificatie, douanewaarde en oorsprong) en bijzondere regelingen. Ten aanzien van het douaneonderdeel wordt tevens ingegaan op de invloed en doorwerking van het internationale douanerecht zoals vastgesteld door de Wereldhandelsorganisatie, en op de juridische instrumenten zoals ontwikkeld door de Werelddouaneorganisatie. Daarnaast wordt aandacht besteed aan de heffing van accijnzen.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>Na het volgen van dit vak is de student in staat om:

column2: • zelfstandig complexe vraagstukken vanuit douane- en accijnsrechtelijk perspectief te analyseren en op te lossen op het gebied van douaneschuld, classificatie, oorsprong, douanewaarde, douaneprocessen, -procedures, -regelingen, -bestemmingen en -formaliteiten, belastbare accijnsgoederen, het Europese accijnssysteem (schorsingsregime, uitslag tot verbruik en heffingsbevoegdheid) en accijnsuitzonderingen en -vrijstellingen;
• de uitgangspunten en fundamenten van het Europese douanerecht en accijnzen te benoemen, herkennen, begrijpen en onderscheiden;
• de samenhang en de verschillen tussen de heffing van douanerechten en accijnzen te analyseren;
• samen te werken met medestudenten op een fiscaal multidisciplinair terrein;
• een fiscaaltechnisch onderwerp te presenteren ten overstaan van zijn/haar medestudenten en daarbij blijk te geven van beheersing van presentatietechnieken;
• zelfstandig een aangedragen fiscaaltechnische probleemstelling te analyseren, zich daarover een mening te vormen en deze te beargumenteren op een gedegen wetenschappelijke wijze;
• de analyse en argumentatie t.a.v. een fiscaal juridisch vraagstuk begrijpelijk en overtuigend weer te geven in een verhandeling.

column1: In Northern Europe, the late seventeenth and early eighteenth centuries saw the first proliferation of the Enlightenment – a cultural movement characterized by its pleas in favor of toleration, its opposition to ‘prejudices’, its fascination with the results achieved by the ‘Scientific Revolution’ as well as by its proposals for societal reforms. Philosophers played a crucial role in articulating its program. In this course we start close at home, for it was Pierre Bayle, ‘le philosophe de Rotterdam’, whose attacks on religious prejudices and whose demands for toleration would serve later generations of enlightened authors as a major source of inspiration. Next, we will turn to France, and to Montesquieu and Voltaire in particular. In France a new cultural phenomenon emerges: the philosophe, witty, sociable, and fiercely critical of received tradition. Many French authors start reading British philosophers, and in this course we will deal with both Berkeley and Hume, and we will wrap up this overview of the early stages of the Enlightenment with a discussion of the Scottish Enlightenment, including Adam Smith. In an accompanying (facultative) study group we will read one of Hume’s enduring masterpieces: Dialogues concerning Natural Religion.

column2: <title></title>
<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: To fulltime students of Philosophy the seminars are compulsory.

Having completed this course, students will be familiar with some of the main ideas put forward by Pierre Bayle. They will understand the main characteristics of ‘British empiricism’. They will be able to distinguish some of the main differences between the French and the Scottish Enlightenment. They will develop some awareness of the historical contingency of the history of eighteenth-century philosophy
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/89863,2019,Early Modern Political Philosophy,Engels,Erasmus University College,,['dr. JP Kloeg', 'prof.dr. JA van Ruler']",,"Inhoud

column1: Politics speaks to us all. Some of us are involved only as citizens; others also as activists, analysts, reporters, or academics. The concepts we use, the positions we defend and the various practices we take part in belong to a tradition of thought that is as rich as it is fundamental to understanding our own society and politics in general. This course offers an overview of the most influential thinkers and themes of political philosophy from the Renaissance to the Enlightenment.

The week-by-week activities of the course will centre around an influential theorist and one of his key contributions. For example, Thomas Hobbes' innovative theory of sovereignty continues to have an enormous influence on work in the fields of international relations, sociology, political theory, history, and philosophy. By introducing such ideas in their historical context we can make them meaningful in terms of the problems the theorist meant to address; conversely, by having a conceptual interest in their theories we can read them in a way that emphasises the relevance of these classic works to our present world. For this reason, the orientation of the course will be both philosophical and historical. The course is a must for
anyone interested in the meaning and history of such concepts as virtue, sovereignty, power and rights.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>After completing this course, students are able to:

column2: • formulate and explain the basic themes of political philosophy from the Early Modern Era, as well as their interrelation;
• relate thinkers and themes of Early Modern political philosophy to politics in the present day;
• formulate the difference between institutional approaches to the analysis of society and those focusing on the person of the leader;
• relate utopianism to its roots in Thomas More, and to explain the relationship between utopianism and interpretations of politics as a moral enterprise;
• explain the relationship between the classical/humanist concept of ‘virtue’ and Machiavelli’s concept of virtu;
• define and analyze the ‘turn to nature’ in Machiavelli’s political philosophy and subsequent authors;
• describe the importance of Hobbes to liberalism, e.g. in terms of consent;
• explain the nature and necessity of sovereignty in Hobbes’ political philosophy;
• connect the concept of democracy to Spinoza’s legacy;
• relate Spinoza’s naturalism to his support for democracy and tolerance;
• relate Montesquieu’s concept of liberty to his philosophical forebears as well as later political developments;
• explain Montesquieu’s ideas on adapting laws to contextual factors;
• describe Rousseau’s views on human nature and the corruption of society;
• explain Rousseau’s conception of the general will.

column4: In dit blok staan drie groepen psychische stoornissen centraal die te maken hebben met de basisbehoeften van de mens: eten, seks en slapen. Eetstoornissen zijn de afgelopen decennia steeds meer voor het voetlicht gekomen. Zowel in de wetenschap als in de media wordt er relatief veel aandacht aan besteed. Maar wat is er nu eigenlijk precies over bekend?

Seksuele stoornissen zijn veelal een taboe voor de cliënt, maar zijn vaak ook voor de psycholoog niet het makkelijkste onderwerp om over te beginnen. Des te belangrijker dus om er in de opleiding aandacht aan te besteden. Welke seksuele disfuncties kunnen we tegenkomen bij mannen en vrouwen, wat is er bekend over de achterliggende mechanismen, en hoe kunnen deze stoornissen het best behandeld worden?

Aan slaapstoornissen wordt in het psychologisch wetenschappelijk onderzoek nog relatief weinig aandacht besteed. In de praktijk is het echter één van de meest voorkomende stoornissen, die ook vaak als comorbide stoornis optreedt, en nadelige consequenties heeft voor ons psychisch- en sociaal functioneren. Voor een klinisch psycholoog daarom van belang om hier kennis over te hebben.

In dit blok komen van alle hierboven genoemde stoornissen de verschijningsvormen en theoretische verklaringsmodellen aan bod. Tevens wordt er aandacht besteed aan de verschillende behandelingsmethoden en de effectiviteit hiervan. Hoewel het zwaartepunt ligt bij dergelijke psychopathologie in volwassenen, wordt deze problematiek in kinderen en adolescenten ook behandeld in dit blok.

In het blok zal ook aandacht besteed worden aan psychodynamische psychodiagnostiek. In dit blok staan enkele projectieve tests centraal, namelijk de Defense Style Questionnaire, de Rorschachtest en de Thematische Apperceptie test. Er wordt niet alleen uitgebreid ingegaan op de inhoud van deze tests, maar ook op de betrouwbaarheid, validiteit, scoring en klinische relevantie van deze tests.
De diagnostiekopdracht is een onderdeel van de eisen voor het behalen van de Basisaantekening Psychodiagnostiek van het Nederlands Instituut van Psychologen (NIP).

column2: </body>

column3: Doel van dit blok is kennis verwerven over recente wetenschappelijke inzichten met betrekking tot de verschijningsvormen, theoretische verklaringsmodellen en behandelmethoden van eetstoornissen, seksuele stoornissen en slaapstoornissen bij zowel volwassenen als kinderen en adolescenten.

column4: Aan het eind van dit blok, heb je substantiële kennis van …

column5: de prevalentie, etiologie en (evidence-based) behandeling van anorexia nervosa;
de prevalentie, etiologie en (evidence-based) behandeling van bulimia nervosa;
de prevalentie, etiologie en (evidence-based) behandeling van de eetbuistoornis;
eetproblematiek bij kinderen;
psychologische factoren die een rol spelen bij obesitas;
de rol die lichaamsbeeld en zelfwaardering spelen bij eetstoornissen;
de belangrijkste (neuro)biologische principes van seksualiteit;
de seksuele responscyclus;
de (informatie ver)werking van het seksuele systeem;
de prevalentie, etiologie en behandeling van seksuele stoornissen bij de man;
de prevalentie, etiologie en behandeling van seksuele stoornissen bij de vrouw;
de effecten van (farmacotherapie bij) psychiatrische stoornissen op seksualiteit;

column4: Tevens heb je aan het eind van dit blok basale kennis van …

column5: de prevalentie, etiologie en psychologische behandeling van slaapstoornissen;
de meetpretentie, validiteit en scoring van de Defense Style Questionnaire;
de meetpretentie, betrouwbaarheid, validiteit, testafname en scoring van de Rorschach-test;
de meetpretentie, betrouwbaarheid, validiteit, testafname en scoring van de Thematische Apperceptie Test (TAT).

column1: <body>Econometrics is characterized by the combination of economic research questions, use of empirical data, application of statistical and mathematical methods, and the use of software to estimate and evaluate models. All these topics are extensively discussed in the lectures and practised in the tutorials.

column2: • Lectures and exercise lectures: Introduction to econometrics, research questions, methods. The linear regression model (simple and multiple), method of least squares, testing. Non-linear models, maximum likelihood, some asymptotic theory of estimation and testing. The models and methods are motivated by economic applications and applied in practical examples. The required econometric methods make intensive use of earlier courses in the programme, in particular statistics, matrix algebra and analysis.
• Tutorials: Exercises on theory and applications. Further, some tutorials consist of computer sessions to apply econometric techniques by means of the software package EViews.
<title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>
• Learn the mathematical structure and statistical properties of linear and non-linear regression models by means of matrix methods and statistical analysis.
• Understand the process of econometric modelling as an interplay of economic insights, data properties, and statistical model assumptions.
• Get experienced in the mathematical analysis and statistical evaluation of econometric models.
• Get experienced in the practical interpretation of outcomes of econometric analysis and in choosing between alternative models and methods.
• Get practical experience in analysing economic data by means of econometric software on the PC.
<title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>The lectures are a follow-up on the lectures in Econometrics 1. The following topics will be discussed:

column2: • Models with heteroskedasticity and/or serial correlation
• Models with endogenous regressors
• Models for limited dependent variables (logit, probit, multinomial)

column1: After this course the student will have practical and theoretical knowledge of various extensions of the linear model (among which: heteroskedasticity, serial correlation, endogeneity). The student will also have knowledge of models for limited dependent variables (logit model, probit model, multinomial).
The student will be able to apply the theory in practice, and will also gain experience in the analysis of economic data using Eviews.</body>

column1: <body>Het vakgebied econometrie wordt gekenmerkt door een combinatie van economische vraagstellingen, gebruik van empirische gegevens, toepassing van statistische en wiskundige methoden, en gebruik van software om modellen te schatten en te evalueren. Al deze onderwerpen komen uitgebreid aan de orde in de hoorcolleges en worden geoefend bij de sommencolleges en in de practica.

column2: • Hoorcollege en sommencollege: Inleiding econometrie, vraagstellingen, modellen, methoden. Het lineaire regressiemodel (enkelvoudig en meervoudig), methode van kleinste kwadraten, toetsen. Niet-lineaire modellen, maximale aannemelijkheid, enige asymptotische theorie van schatten en toetsen. De modellen en methoden worden gemotiveerd vanuit economische toepassingen en toegepast in praktische voorbeelden. De benodigde econometrische methoden maken intensief gebruik van eerdere vakken uit het programma, met name statistiek, lineaire algebra en analyse.
• Practicum: Opgaven over theorie en toepassingen. Voorts wordt enige malen een computer-practicum gehouden, waar econometrische technieken worden toegepast met het pakket EViews.
<title></title>
<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>
• Leren van de wiskundige structuur en de statistische eigenschappen van lineaire en niet-lineaire regressiemodellen, door middel van matrixmethoden en statistische analyse.
• De processen van het econometrische modelleren als snijvlak van economische inzichten, data eigenschappen en statistische modelaannames begrijpen.
• Vertrouwd raken met het analyseren van de wiskundige en statistische structuur van econometrische modellen.
• Vertrouwd raken met de praktische interpretatie van de uitkomsten van econometrische analyse en het kiezen tussen alternatieve modellen en methoden.
• Opdoen van praktische ervaring met het analyseren van economische data met behulp van econometrische software op een PC.

<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Na dit college heeft de student kennis van de theorie over diverse uitbreidingen van het lineaire model (waaronder: heteroskedasticiteit, seriecorrelatie, endogeniteit). Daarnaast heeft de student kennis van modellen voor keuzegedrag (logit, probit, multinomiale variabelen).
De student kan de theorie ook daadwerkelijk toepassen in de praktijk, en heeft ook ervaring met het zelf analyseren van economische data met behulp van Eviews.

column1: This course is designed for students who are interested in an analytical understanding of European integration that goes beyond ‘black letter law’, reflecting the growing need of more interdisciplinary studies of European integration. Students will learn to use the economics tool box in order to comprehend and to evaluate law and policy proposals towards more (or less) European integration.

The teaching content consists of two parts. The first part of the lecture is dedicated to the theoretical understanding of economic integration, including a basic understanding of international trade theory. Topics are: theorem of comparative advantages, free trade, protection, tariffs, stages of integration and federalism theory. Emphasis is placed on a qualitative understanding of these topics. The second part of the lecture applies the gained theoretical insights to topical problems of European integration. Topics are, for example: the concept of regulatory competition, which will be linked to the famous ECJ decisions ‘Cassis de Dijon’ and ‘Centros’, European state aid control and European financial regulation

column1: <body>After having completed this course successfully, a student will be able to:

column2: • Describe and analyze the historical and institutional framework of European integration as well as the economic theories dealing with integration issues.
• Analyze and assess the interrelation between the political process and European economic integration.
• Develop ways of addressing legal problems with the help of economic theories and identifying further developments in international and European Union law.
• Assess and critically discuss on European integration issues.

column1: <body>This 8-ECTS course aims at giving students an overview of the most important insights from the economic analysis of private law. It combines economic analysis of property law, tort law, and contract law. As far as property law is concerned, the course integrates the legal and the economic approach to ownership and illustrates costs and benefits of different ways to protect entitlements. As far as tort law is concerned, the course offers a comparative analysis of the legal principles from an economic perspective, particularly regarding the structure of liability, the damage compensation, and the insurance. As far as contract law is concerned, the course illustrates its goals and functions from an economic perspective. Moreover, it aims to provide a functional understanding of the spectrum of feasible contracts and of their use in legal practice.</body>

column1: This course offers an introduction to the economic analysis of regulation, which is broadly interpreted as government intervention in market processes. The course illustrates the purposes of regulatory intervention from a welfare economics perspective, and it discusses the tension between public and private interest in regulatory choices. A special focus of this course is on issues of European regulation and on cost-benefit analysis.

column1: During the past decade, the concept of creative economy along with that of creative industries have experienced an intensifying academic research and policy attention. The course critically investigates theories and issues linked to culture, creativity, economy and cities. It will provide students with a contrasting set of views on the role of cultural and creative industries in cities through the use of theories, case studies and fieldtrips. Topics discussed include: the role of culture and creativity in   cities across centuries, the emergence of a creative city (e.g. a fashion capital), the economic geography of cultural production, cultural-led urban (re)generation, gentrification, circular economy, cultural intermediaries, (temporary) clusters, the black box of urban growth. We emphasize an analytical approach in understanding the dynamic development of cultural and creative industries and place, and the issues that arise from them.

column2: • The maximum number of participants is 30.

• This course is only open to Pre-Master students in Cultural Economics and Entrepreneurship, BA students in International Bachelor Arts and Culture Studies (IBACS) and BA Algemene Cultuurwetenschappen

column1: In this seminar students will acquire knowledge and understanding of the spatial dimension and characteristics of creativity as well as the connections between the development of cultural and creative industries and the growth of cities and regions. Special attention is dedicated the role cultural and creative industries play in supporting the transition to the circular economy.
At the end of the course students should be able:

column2: • To develop knowledge and understanding of theories applied to the spatial dimensions of creativity;
• To apply concepts and theories to specific case studies in group presentations, discussions and written assignments;
• To explain main issues and limitations of theories; critically assess the value and relevance of models, concepts and theories.

column1: The minor aims to broaden as well as deepen the knowledge and understanding of economics for individuals trained in econometrics on several dimensions.

This module begins with an introduction to/refresher of game theory to lay the methodological foundations. In the rest of the course we consider classical strategic problems of individual interaction such as

column2: • problems of coordination
• problems of cooperationcommunication  and information exchange (cheap talk, persuasion, signalling)
• bargaining
• contests & tournaments

column1: After a general analysis of these strategic situations, we consider and discuss their economic applications and relevance.
In this module we will study the long run behaviour of economy and its short-run fluctuations.
In the first part (long-run), we will cover economic growth and unemployment.
In the second part (short-run), the focus will be on the consumption, investment and asset prices’ determination.
The models presented in this course are an introduction to modern macroeconomics and build on the 1st year macroeconomics course. We will study the applications of the models using academic papers.
The module is about micro-econometric empirical strategies used to estimate causal relationships that are of interest to economists. These include:

column2: • Lab & field experiments
• Randomized control trials
• Difference-in-differences
• Propensity score matching
• Instrumental variables
• Regression discontinuity

column1: The module will describe the advantages (and disadvantages) of these different empirical strategies to identify the causal effect of a treatment. Students will learn what kind of identifying assumptions different empirical strategies are based on. We will also appraise which data requirements have to be met for the successful application of a particular strategy.
This will be done, for each method in turn, by:

column2: • Reviewing the econometric theory behind the various methods
• Go through empirical papers which have successfully applied these

column1: In general, a particular emphasis of this minor is the development of economic intuition.

column1: The global financial and economic crisis and the subsequent European sovereign debt and financial crisis have broad the importance of the regulation of economic and monetary integration, as well as the supervision of financial markets in the European internal market to the forefront. The complexity of institutional and substantive rules governing these areas of European Union law, as well as the (political) economic arguments that often dominate the legal (policy) debate may explain why in the past these areas of law have received considerably less attention from lawyers and in law school curricular than other areas of European Union law. However, due to the proliferation of rules in recent years and the likelihood of further regulation, there is a growing demand for specialized knowledge among national, European and international (government) organizations, multinational law firms and consultancy firms.

The course first of all addresses the principles and rules governing the European economic and monetary union (EMU). Here the focus comes to rest on the general characteristics of EMU and its shortcomings (namely asymmetric integration), the economic and legal objectives and principles underlying economic policy coordination, the different Union and extra-Union instruments that define the preventive and corrective arms of the Stability and Growth Pact and the macroeconomic imbalances procedure (namely Six Pack, Two Pack, Fiscal Compact), the conditions for granting financial assistance to Member States (namely Articles 122(1), 125 TFEU & ESM Treaty), as well as the institutional position and tasks of the European System of Central Banks and the European Central Bank.

The course moreover concentrates on the principles and rules governing the European System of Financial Supervision and the so-called European Banking Union. Here the focus lies on the overall supervisory architecture (namely the role of the three European supervisory authorities & the ECB’s Supervisory Board), an overview of the main features of the Single Supervisory Mechanism (namely based on Regulations (EU) No 1024/2013 and No 1022/2013), as well as the main features of the Single Resolution Mechanism (Regulation (EU) No 806/2014) and of the Single Resolution Fund.

Throughout the course particular attention will be paid to (1) explaining the (political) economic rationale for institutional arrangements and (2) highlighting the close link between economic and monetary integration, but also between EMU and the regulation and supervision of financial markets in the EU that stress the need for an integrated approach to the study of these fields of law. With regard to (1) the course builds on the knowledge acquired namely in block 1 (Research & Writing Skills) and block 3 (Foundations of European Economic Integration) of the master.

column1: <body>As a result of this course, a student should be able to independently:

column2: • describe, analyse and assess the legal framework relevant to EMU and European System of Financial Supervision, and its systemic and the methodological factors thereof (learning objective 1, 4, 8)

• independently analyse and assess the economic and political economy rationale underlying the legal framework relevant to EMU and European System of Financial Supervision (learning objective 3, 5, 8)

• independently develop, conduct and account for academic research, and, based on this, provide a well-reasoned opinion of his/her own, as well as communicate, in writing as well as orally, scientifically justified research and legal advice, to legal specialists and to non-legal specialist audiences (learning objective 9, 11)

column1: This course focuses on two separate, yet related aspects of the economy by introducing both the micro- as well as the macro-economic viewpoint.
The Micro-economics part of the course examines three interrelated questions:

column2: • how individuals and firms make choices,
• in what way these choices interact in different markets and
• how businesses and managers adjust their decision making process to the various characteristics of the markets in which they are active.

column1: This first part of the course focuses on developing a sound understanding of the basic principles of consumer choice and the efficient use of inputs by firms. We then bring consumers and firms to the market place. Here we study how different market structures (perfect competition, monopoly, oligopoly, monopolistic competition) affect pricing and the allocation of resources. A strong emphasis is placed on the applicability of theories, principles and concepts to actual situations and concrete management problem. The skills developed during the course enable the students to (1) understand concrete situations and (2) to have an impact on these situations.

The second part of the course is about macro-economics, or the general environment in which firms are active. In macroeconomics the focus is on nations. Together these nations form the global economy. This introductory course aims to familiarize students with the most important concepts and models from (international) macroeconomics. Important macroeconomic topics will be discussed such as macroeconomic policies, key macroeconomic variables and their interrelationships, globalization, and regional integration agreements. We will also relate to relevant topics in today’s business climate. For example, topics include changing demands due to European integration, rise of emerging markets, the recent financial crisis, and climate change. It also can be beneficial as you write your Strategic Business Plan as it allows you to consider the broader environment in which firms formulate and implement their strategies.

column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>
• To understand consumer and producer behavior and its impact on markets;
• To grasp basic economic theories and principles and their impact on business strategies and government policies;
• To develop an understanding of the basic market structures and what they imply for a strategy of a company;
• To apply the tools of microeconomics to solve business as well some economic problems;
• To name important macroeconomic variables and explain their interrelations;
• To explain how governments and central banks can influence the economy;
• To interpret important international developments and develop a critical stance towards the current macroeconomic environment we live in;
• To describe how the macroeconomic context of firms are characterized and explain how (international) firms affect each other.

column1: <body>Almost all socio-economic characteristics (e.g., educational attainment, occupation, and income) have been shown to be moderately heritable. This makes it possible to identify specific genes that are related to socio-economic differences among individuals and to investigate how these genes interact with environmental factors. For example, which genetic factors contribute to educational attainment and do specific family environments moderate the genetic susceptibility to perform well in school? In this course, students are introduced to key concepts and state-of-the-art computer tools in genetics. The goal of this course is to make students familiar with the economic consequences developments in genetics can have, and to reflect on the ethical aspects of these consequences. This course covers topics such as the nature vs. nurture debate, estimation and interpretation of heritability, gene discovery, and genetic prediction. Moreover, the students become familiar with big data analysis by performing basic genetic analyses using specialized statistical software.</body>

column1: Historical developments, political choices, and societal structures strongly influence the organization of health care systems across countries. The main purpose of this course is to provide an introduction to various conceptual frameworks that help you to understand and use economic principles applied to health care systems. The course will deal with theory of supply and demand in health care, the crucial role of (asymmetry in) information, provider payment incentives, private and social health insurance, theory and practice of managed competition, organization and financing of long-term care, and the public/private mix in the financing and provision of care. The course looks at how health care systems, in the Netherlands and in other developed countries, deal with important policy issues like competition and regulation, solidarity, and the role of voluntary supplementary health insurance.

column2: • 14 plenary meetings of 90 minutes with interactive lectures
• 1 guest lecture of 90 minutes
• 1 meeting for questions and answers
• several meetings in which students work in groups on assignments and peer review / feedback

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>By the end of this course students are able to:

column2: • understand and explain the economic complexities of health care (systems) that are relevant for health policy.

• classify different types of health care systems, describe how these systems function in terms of the organization and financing of health care, and explain the implications thereof for efficiency and equity in health care.
• investigate the comparative performance of health care systems and to use such an analysis to infer implications for health policy.

column1: <body>The course aims at outlining the contribution of economics to the study of the cultural heritage. Students will learn about the cultural-economic perspective on cultural heritage and sites and their role for the economy. The main issues considered are:

column2: • The evolution of the concept of cultural heritage.
• Economic concepts applied to cultural heritage.
• Cultural heritage policies
• Conventions and other protection instruments
• Conservation and regeneration of cultural heritage
• Evaluation methods and their limits
• Cultural heritage and tourism
• Cultural heritage and development
<title></title>
<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: After completing the course, students should have a wide-ranging knowledge and critical understanding of the cultural economic perspective on cultural heritage. They will be aware of the relevance of economic concepts and management issues related to cultural heritage and sites as well as of the main policy dilemmas arising in this field. The course gives specific attention to the connection between theory and practice referring to several case studies.
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/87003,2019,Economics of Cultural Tourism,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,['dr. A Mignosa'],,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

The course will introduce the main concepts related to tourism in general: its development, its economic impact, the main definitions and concepts (tourist, visitor, excursionist, carrying capacity of a destination), and the trends characterizing the sector and modifying it. The course will then focus on cultural tourism: a specific branch of tourism that is expanding though it is still difficult to identify and define. The economic approach will highlight the characteristics of the sector, its potential for the economic development of regions but also the risks it can entail. The course will provide a critical review of the virtuous-vicious relationship between tourism and culture. It will thus highlight the risks that tourism can entail (for example in terms of wear and tear of WH sites) but also the strategies that can be applied to avoid or, at least, reduce these risks.

Every week the lecturer will introduce a theme illustrating the main theoretical notions and some examples. The week after a group of students will lead the class making a presentation that provides a thorough analysis of the same topic using a case study.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

The aim of this course is to teach students the main concepts from the economics of tourism, considering the evolution and development of the sector through time, focusing in particularly on the niche of cultural tourism. Based on a critical engagement with the fundamental theories and empirical literature, students are challenged to identify and comment the effects, opportunities and challenges related to cultural tourism. Students will improve their presentation and writing skills by doing presentations in class and writing a final essay.

column1: The vast increase in digital insecurity - posed by ransomware, DDoS attacks, and data breaches amongst others - requires an intelligent cyber security strategy. However, very little is known regarding the social costs and benefits of investing in cyber security. This is worrisome: cyber security expenditures will rise exponentially in the future as mankind becomes increasingly dependent on the digital world. Cyber security is now a common topic on the agendas of SME’s, large corporations, global enterprises, and governments.

In this course, we will cover several security related topics from an interdisciplinary perspective. From an economics point we will discuss the economic drivers and effectiveness of security investments, incentive structures and how they affect corporate strategy, and how scammers and cyber criminals make money. From a behavioral perspective we will cover how to achieve a corporate security culture and the role that employees play in cyber security. From a law perspective we will discuss novel legal instruments such as the possibility for insurance against cyber risks, the option to cover these risks by means of pooling, and the EU data breach notification obligation in the GDPR. Together, this course will provide a comprehensive and interdisciplinary overview of the different factors that influence the level of cybersecurity in government and industry.

column1: The seminar looks at the fashion industry as one of the creative industries. It aims to facilitate students’ knowledge and understanding of how the industry works. The seminar will confront students with the most recent theories linked to the characteristics, the demand, the supply and intermediaries for fashion products as well the sustainability issues in the fashion industry. We emphasize an analytical approach in understanding the dynamic development of the fashion industry. In doing so, we will discuss relevant literature and specific cases through student presentations, class discussion and field trips. Students will focus on one fashion product/firm/market and carry out research based on scholarly literature, resulting in an individual essay and in a group poster presentation.
The maximum number of students is 30.

column2: • Priority is given to bachelor students from Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication (7 students from BA Geschiedenis or IBHistory, 7 students from BA ACW or IBACS, 7 students from IBCoM, 3 exchange students, 9 students from other faculties or universities).

• It is not allowed to take this course as an individual course; students are required to take the entire Minor Fashion Industry of 15 ECTs. Minor students should obtain a pass mark for each of the three course; it is not possible to compensate for a score below the pass mark.

• Admission requirements: Proficiency in spoken and written English is essential [VWO-final examination grade: 7 or higher / TOEFL-test: minimum score 580 (paper-based), 237 (computer- based) or 92 (internet-based) / IELTS-test: minimum of 7(overall band)]

column1: In academia, business environment and policy-making circles the past decade has given rise to a growing acknowledgment of the design industries as paradigmatic sectors of post-industrial economies, “cognitive-cultural” capitalism, or even better “neo-industrial” economies, in which production increasingly relies on symbolic and aesthetic considerations as well as on local specificities. The seminar provides a forum for discussion of the week's topic, reading material, case studies and fieldtrips. Students are expected to read and discuss the literature, summarize it for discussion in class and apply it to specific cases. A critical approach is encouraged. Topics covered in the course, among others: characteristics of design products; demand for design products; economic and spatial organization of design industries; labour market for designers; intermediaries, temporary clusters and global pipelines; sustainability, circular economy and design industries. Students will focus on design, fashion or architecture industries and carry out research based on scholarly literature, resulting in an individual essay and in a group poster presentation. This course builds further upon the courses in Term 1 and 2, and it is connected to topics that students will encounter in their master thesis.

column2: • The maximum number of participants is 25.
• It is not allowed to follow the seminar “Economics of Fashion, Design and Architecture” together with the seminar “Heritage and Fashion”

column1: The seminar wishes to facilitate students’ knowledge and understanding of the economic and spatial characteristics of the design industries - in particular fashion, design and architecture. We emphasize an analytical approach in understanding the dynamic development of the design industries. Special attention is dedicated the role design industries play in supporting the transition to the circular economy. In doing so, we will discuss relevant literature and specific cases through student presentation, class discussion and field trips.

column1: This course provides essential insights for anyone interested in the organization of firm production which becomes increasingly complex in a globalizing world. The course first looks at several theories to explain how firms govern production. In particular, it analyses how moral hazard in production, transaction cost economics and hold-up problems affect the decision of firms to vertically integrate along the production chain. In the last part of the course the relevance and effects of the broader institutional environment (rule of law, corruption, etc.) on the economic performance is discussed. Throughout the course the theoretical insights are supported by empirical applications. Note that a basic knowledge of mathematics (e.g. derivatives, optimization) and econometrics is needed to succeed in this course.

column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

• Describe the importance of moral hazard, transaction costs, hold-up problems and knowledge dissipation for the governance of production chains, building on theoretical arguments and empirical evidence.
• Clarify competition policy issues related to vertical integration and long term contracts using insights from the literature on the governance of production chains.
• Critically analyse a firm’s governance strategy based on data collection and sound theoretical arguments.
• Interpret empirical evidence in the academic literature on firm governance and vertical integration.
• Solve economic models analysing firm governance issues and vertical integration.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/88771,2019,Economics of Health and Health Care,Engels,Erasmus School of Health Policy & Management,,['dr. M Tenand', 'dr. PLH Bakx', 'J Stöckel, MSc', 'JAM Bom', 'M Bar', 'MS Perry-Duxbury, MSc', 'prof.dr. EKA Van Doorslaer']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

This course builds on Economics and Financing of Health Care, in which the principles of health economics and health care financing are explained. This course uses the tools and concepts discussed in that course to analyse and compare health and health care at the macro or system level. The performance of health care systems may be evaluated by analysing whether the outcomes are efficient and equitable. Therefore, this course consists of three parts.

The first part is about the relationships between health, health care and income. Understanding these relationships is an important goal in its own right, but also provides some of the building blocks that are necessary for the definition and measurement of equity (part 2) and efficiency (part 3). In each of the three parts, the main focus is on applying the analytical framework – and evaluating how other researchers’ applied it – to compare the performance of developed and less developed countries and discuss the aspects of health care systems and their performance in a structured manner.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>After taking this course, students are able to:

column2: • Explain why equity and efficiency are important health system performance indicators
• Apply the tools that are used to measure equity and efficiency of health systems
• Judge whether the measures of equity and efficiency are used in a valid and meaningful way in international comparative analyses of health care system functioning
• Comment on scientific articles on health system performance from top journals in the field of health economics

column1: <body>Today both developed and developing countries are searching for ways to foster economic growth. Innovation is considered to be a major force for economic growth. The objective of this course is to provide students with a comprehensive and advanced understanding of what innovation is, how innovation is organised and diffused, how internal and external (industry) factors impact on innovation, and what the role is of different actors involved in innovation such as different types of firms (start-ups, small firms and large firms) banks and venture capitalists.</body>

column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

• Students are able to reproduce and interpret main concepts and characteristics of innovation; economic incentives for innovation; the organization and diffusion of innovation; the economic consequences of innovation; and the economic rationale of public policies for fostering innovation.

• Students apply concepts, theories and paradigms of innovation to analyze complex and current issues of a (business) economics nature such as industry developments and differences, the role of entrepreneurs in fostering innovation and standards races.

• Students analyze developments related to innovation (such as the emergence of industrial clusters and the increased globalization of specialized production) from several perspectives and then explain these developments based on the tension between those different perspectives.
• Students present the results of an industry or company analysis.

<body>Game theory is the study of strategic interaction. It is a structured approach to analyzing situations in which there is room for cooperation and conflict. Such situations are abundant in markets, organizations, and beyond. This course provides an inGame theory is the study of strategic interaction. It is a structured approach to analyzing situations in which there is room for cooperation and conflict. Such situations are abundant in markets, organizations, and beyond. This course provides an introduction to the use of game theory in a variety of contexts, in particular, bargaining and negotiation, contracting, and auctions. The emphasis of the course is on developing skills to approach problems in a structured and systematic manner. The course aims to promote a careful approach to strategic situations, without undue emphasis on technicalities. The reading material assigned for this course is illustrative of the sort of game-theoretic reasoning this course seeks to promote. Prior knowledge of game theory is not required.troduction to the use of game theory in a variety of contexts, in particular, bargaining and negotiation, contracting, and auctions. column1: This course studies markets and organizations, by focusing on:
1. auctions and other competitive bidding processes
3. contracting, both withing and between organizations.
The course makes use of game theory to analyse these processes in which asymetric information often play a key role.  The relevant parts of game theory are covered in the course.

Whereas introductory courses to microeconomics leave the impression that markets come about without any conscious design, many markets are organized with certain goals in mind. Auctions and competitive bidding processes more generally are an interesting area to study this phenomenon. What are the outcomes that the auctioneer has in mind when designing the auction? How can an auctioneer stimulate competition and hinder collusion during the bidding process? Vice versa, how can a bidder improve her chances of winning the desired items without paying too much?

A second part of the course deals with contracts. Examples include (i) labor contracts within organizations and between an organization and somebody who is self-employed and (ii) procurement contracts. As with the design of auctions, we consider two levels of analysis that are intimately related: how to design a contract and how to act given the contract.

Finally, we discuss bargaining and negotiating, common phenomena in markets and organizations. Where there is room for cooperation, mutual gains and conflict, in the short run or in the long run, the ability to optimize the negotiation process is an asset, as is the skill to bargain in a format one has not chosen.

We make use of a book and a few articles. The book Games, Strategies and Managers by the late economist John McMillan discusses some theory and many applications, ranging from CEO pay, to international trade negotiations, to bidding for the rights to broadcast the Olympic Games.  It was written to publicize the power of game-theoretic reasoning in everyday situations.  The book The Strategy of Conflict - of which we discuss some chapters that are also available as journal articles - by the late social scientist Thomas Schelling was the outcome of the author’s experience with and reflection upon international relations and nuclear tactics at the height of the Cold War.  His analysis earned him the Nobel Prize in economics in 2005.

column1: Traditionally, the firm is treated as a structure where inputs are transformed into output. Yet, 'the firm' is not a decision-making unit. Rather, production is shaped by the decisions of people within the organisation. People involved in an organisation (or, more generally, in any transaction) will have different objectives, which may hamper cooperation.

The issues we will discuss include the effects and limitations of various instruments that may improve efficiency, such as property rights, contracts, financial and non-financial incentives, and organisational structure. Throughout, we take a microeconomic perspective.

column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>
• Understand and apply important concepts, tools, and theories regarding the behaviour of people in organisations.
• Recognise situations where there may be conflicts of interest between people, analyse the effects of the conflict of interest, and assess how interests could be (better) aligned.
• Independently recognise how institutional and organisational features have developed to cope with conflicting interests between people.
• Critically assess scientific literature in the field of Organisational Economics.

column1: The course integrates insights from industrial organisation and strategy research while building upon a strong theoretical and empirical foundation.
1. First, the course discusses the concept of real options as a tool to make investment decisions under uncertainty.
2. The second part examines investments in research and development and advertising.
3. The last part analyzes strategies for particular types of goods and industries.

The topics are of interest to anyone with both a theoretical and a professional interest in strategic decision making at the firm level. As the course will use basic micro-theory, some knowledge in this field (monopoly, oligopoly, Stackelberg, perfect competition) and the associated mathematics is required.</body>

column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>
• Students will understand under which circumstances real options theory helps to make better managerial decisions.
• Students will understand how and when irreversible investments in research and development and advertizing lead to a sustainable competitive advantage.
• Students will understand how sector and product contact have an impact on managerial decision making.
• Students will be able to calculate the value of conditional investments under uncertainty.

column1: <body>This course provides a thorough understanding of a number of key topics within the economics of taxation. The course is largely positive in its scope but also provides a few normative (i.e., prescriptive) insights.

The course addresses the following questions and more: Under which conditions is the laissez-faire market equilibrium efficient? How does taxation interfere with efficiency? Who carries the burden of taxation? How does this depend on individual rationality assumptions? How may income taxes help improve the distribution of resources? How does the optimal income tax differ from the one chosen by democratically elected officials? How might taxation help improve efficiency when dealing with externalities? What about internalities? What determines individuals’ decisions to evade taxes? And to what extent do governments compete for internationally mobile tax bases?

The goal is to understand both the traditional theory on each topic, as well as the state-of-the-art insights generated by current academic research. As such, the required literature for many of the topics consists of recent scholarly papers as well as textbook chapters.

column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>
• To gain knowledge on the principles of public finance.
• To understand how changes in taxes affect decisions to work, consume, and engage in tax evasion.
• To understand how taxes affect market outcomes, efficiency, and the distribution of resources.
• To understand which policies are best suited to tackle problems generated by externalities, internalities, and tax evasion.
• To understand how relaxing rationality assumptions affect the conventional wisdom on the economics of taxation.
• To link insights from public finance to actual policy debates.
• To critically read and understand academic journal articles at the scientific frontier of the economics of taxation.
• To apply basic concepts from microeconomics and mathematics to the study of public economics.

column1: <body>Analyses of the production, distribution, presentation and consumption of performing arts in different countries and in different economic and social systems are discussed. Attention will be paid to functions of the performing arts, programming, audience development, public and private financing, pricing theory, economic geography, marketing concepts, collaboration and economics and innovation in the popular music industry. Students will be trained in analyzing the establishment of cultural institutions in the performing arts. They will be encouraged to analyze and compare the economic aspects of performing arts in different countries. During the course two performing arts organizations will be visited. During guest lectures, students will get first hand experiences from specialists in the sector.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>The aim of the seminar is to acquire comprehension of specific objectives of the performing arts from an economic and a cultural point of view. Students learn to understand the different ways of organizing, financing and developing the production and presentation of the performing arts such as popular music, drama, classical music and so on in different countries.</body>

column1: European countries are noted for the extent of their welfare systems. Education and health care are predominantly publicly funded. Unemployment and disability insurance, as well as income support for the poor, tend to be more generous than on other continents. States are deeply involved in the regulation and financing of pensions. The continued viability of the European social model is hotly debated across the continent. Some question the consistency of generous welfare provisions with maintaining competitiveness in increasingly globalized markets. Others retort that insurance eases transitions through the business cycle and good quality public education raises productivity. Ageing populations strain public pension and health care systems but public financing may help constrain rising health care costs. The contribution of welfare provisions to immigration into and within Europe is highly contested. This course uses economics to cast light on these issues. It separates equity from efficiency goals and analyses the extent to which state involvement in the finance and provision of pensions, insurance, health care and education is justified with respect to economic efficiency. Moving beyond the broad issue of whether the state should be involved in these sectors, the course considers how social policies should be designed to best achieve specific equity and efficiency objectives. After this course you will be:
i) more critical of debates about welfare policies in Europe;
ii) able to distinguish equity from efficiency motivations for social policies;
iii) able analyse the design of welfare policies;
iv) able to assess the validity of empirical analyses of welfare issues;
v) practised in developing a logical, coherent argument.</body>

column3: In deze module wordt ervan uitgegaan dat bestuurskunde- en sociologiestudenten een brede economische basis moeten krijgen omdat ze op verschillende wijze in aanraking kunnen komen met het vakgebied. Bestuurskundigen en sociologen krijgen voortdurend op verschillende plekken, bij departementen, gemeenten en organisaties, te maken met ontwikkelingen, projecten dan wel beleid, waarbij economische principes en instrumentarium toegepast worden om maatschappelijke processen te beïnvloeden. Daarbij komen vier aspecten aan bod:

column5: Micro-economisch gedachtengoed: consumentengedrag, producentengedrag, markt(werking), vraagsturing, collectieve goederen (plus externe effecten) en welvaartsverdelingsvraagstukken.

Macro-economisch gedachtengoed: Uitgaande van vraag- dan wel aanbodgericht beleid, gericht op allocatie, stabilisatie en verdeling, aandacht voor vormgeving en doeltreffendheid van economische politiek, monetair beleid, sociale zekerheid, verdelingsvraagstukken en internationale economische betrekkingen.
Begroting: Inkomsten en uitgaven, normen, besluitvormingsprocessen.
De betekenis van instituties, hun bijdrage aan economische ontwikkeling en economische politiek, en de samenhang tussen hun vormgeving en de effectiviteit van beleid.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/85440,2019,Economisch Beleid & Management Control,Nederlands,Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences,,"['dr. PK Marks', 'dr. SJ Keulen']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Het college Economisch Beleid & Management Control voor het avondprogramma Master Bestuurskunde heeft tot doel studenten een oriëntatie te geven op micro-economie, overheidsfinanciën en management control (bedrijfsvoering). De rode draad in deze module is het economisch beleid, waarbij de rol van de overheid met haar mogelijkheden en beperkingen centraal staat. Als publiek manager zal je sturing moeten geven aan economische problemen. Hierbij is het noodzakelijk om zowel de individuele economische afwegingen te begrijpen, als de (on)mogelijkheden die de overheidsfinanciën te kennen. Via management control kun je hierna beleid opstellen, budgetteren, uitvoeren, monitoren en verantwoorden.

Vragen die tijdens deze module aan de orde komen zijn o.a. hoe functioneren markten, hoe ga je om met schaarse middelen, welke rol speelt de overheid daarbij, hoe zit het begrotingsbeleid in elkaar, en hoe kan ik meten of het gevoerde beleid doeltreffend was.

Het onderwijsprogramma bevat afwisselende werkvormen als hoorcolleges, werkcolleges, en discussiebijeenkomsten. Het precieze rooster zal t.z.t. bekend worden gemaakt. Om met de collegestof te oefenen en later in de praktijk te kunnen brengen krijgen studenten ruim de gelegenheid zelf actuele casussen op te lossen. In het te schrijven paper komen de verschillende oriëntaties terug en laat de student zien dat hij de verschillende mechanismes uit micro-economie, overheidsfinanciën en economisch beleid kan analyseren.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: • De student is in staat om kritisch te reflecteren op de begrippen en mechanismen uit de micro-economie.
• De student kan het micro-economisch instrumentarium, behorende bij de mechanismen, toepassen in beleid en de welvaartsafwegingen die daarbij horen analyseren.
• De student is in staat om te verklaren hoe keuzes gemaakt worden voor overheidsingrijpen, overheidsfinanciën en de omvang van de collectieve sector.
• De student is in staat om de functie van management control en de bijbehorende begrippen uit te leggen.
• De student is in staat om de verschillende mechanismen uit management control toe te passen op een casus.

column1: <body>In this course, we analyse the transition from a linear, oppositional, externalising, identity based discourse on ecology to a circular, inclusive discourse that is based on an ecophilosophical perspective that focuses on differences and relations. Connecting the domains of art, science and politics to philosophy, a threefold ecology (ECO3) is explored and fed back into the current debates on ecology. The broad perspective is the proposition that after the modern enlightenment of the mind 21st century schizoid man is up to a new, medial enlightenment that acknowledges the productive role of technology for the constitution of our self-consciousness.</body>

column1: Acquiring a limited but relevant overview on current philosophical debates on sustainability and ecology and being able to analyze and debate specific ecophilosophical problems concerning the relation between economy, ethics, politics and ecology. To learn to carefully read, understand and critically reflect on selected texts of a diversity of authors that problematize conventional concepts, disclosing new perspectives on ecological issues focused on the transition of philosophy to ecosophy, and being able to transpose these acquired insights to one’s own field of expertise.Acquiring a limited but relevant overview on current philosophical debates on sustainability and ecology and being able to analyze and debate specific ecophilosophical problems concerning the relation between economy, ethics, politics and ecology. • De student kan een goede samenwerking met en tussen leerlingen tot stand brengen.
• De student kan een krachtige en veilige leeromgeving inrichten waarin leerlingen zich op een goede manier leerinhouden van het vakgebied Economie eigenmaken.
• De student kan in groepen leerlingen en in andere contacten met leerlingen een overzichtelijk, ordelijk en taakgericht leef- en werkklimaat tot stand brengen.
• De student kan relevante informatie uitwisselen met collega’s in de school en uitkomsten daarvan benutten.

• De student kan relevante informatie uitwisselen met verzorgers van leerlingen buiten school en daarin zorgen voor afstemming.De student kan eigen opvattingen over het leraarschap en de eigen bekwaamheden als leraar expliciteren, kritisch onderzoeken en verder ontwikkelen op basis van theoretische inzichten en empirische gegevens.
• De student kan vakdidactisch ingrijpen in de leerstof met als doel de verlening van betekenis aan economische begrippen te vergroten.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Vanaf het moment dat we geboren zijn tot aan het eind van ons leven,         blijft         de         mens         nieuwe         dingen         leren.         Soms         maken         we         ons         dingen         vrijwel         automatisch         eigen         en         soms         eist         het         een         extreme         inspanning.         Veel         van         dit         leren         gebeurt         in         een         onderwijssetting,         die         speciaal         ingericht         is         om         bepaalde         kennis         en         vaardigheden         bij         te         brengen.         Maar         hoe         gaat         dat         leren         nu         precies         in         zijn         werk?         Zijn         er         verschillende         vormen         van         leren         en         welke         vorm         is         dan         de         beste?         En         hoe         kun         je         in         je         onderwijs         het         leren         stimuleren?         Wanneer         gaat         dit         leren         fout?         Welke         leerproblemen         kom         je         tegen?         Waarom         kunnen         we         soms         dingen         die         we         geleerd         hebben         in         de         ene         context         wel         goed         toepassen         en         in         een         andere         context         niet?         Deze         en         nog         andere         vragen         over         leren         staan         centraal         in         dit         blok.         Studenten         denken         na         over         deze         vragen         aan         de         hand         van         problemen         uit         de         praktijk         van         onderwijs         en         onderzoek.

column2: <head>

column2: <body>

column3: Op basis van theorieën over leren en ontwikkeling verwerven studenten inzicht in wat er gebeurt en verandert wanneer mensen leren. Studenten zullen vertrouwd raken met thema's zoals leren lezen, misconcepties, transfer, expertise, leermotivatie, leren met multimedia, toetsing en de achtergronden bij het probleemgestuurd onderwijs. Er wordt bij elk van de thema's ook aandacht besteed aan implicaties voor de inrichting van onderwijs.</body>
