column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>

column3: In de onderwijsgroepen wordt gewerkt met verschillende vignetten van somatische zieke patiënten (met of zonder psychische problemen). De hoorcolleges bieden elke week verbreding van het betreffende onderwerp. In de eerste week wordt aandacht besteed aan diagnostiek van psychische problemen bij somatisch zieke patiënten. Psychische problematiek kan het gevolg zijn van ziekte of het ziek zijn en het kan een complicerende factor zijn bij een somatische ziekte. Verder komt het verschil tussen stepped-care en matched-care aan bod. De voorwaarden voor beide worden besproken evenals de voor- en nadelen van deze twee methodieken.

De tweede week gaat over laagdrempelige en kortdurende behandelingen, zoals zelfhulp en e-mental health. Er zijn vele vormen van zelfhulp, zoals zelfhulpgroepen, zelfmanagementprogramma’s en bibliotherapie. Maar kan een behandeling zonder therapeut wel werken? De opkomst van nieuwe media biedt nieuwe mogelijkheden voor de hulpverlening. Zo wordt steeds vaker gebruikgemaakt van internet, e-mail, sms, chat en games in de psychologische hulpverlening. Hoe gaat dat?

In week drie komt een aantal vormen van psychologische behandeling bij somatische patiënten aan bod. Het doel is klachtvermindering en het verbeteren van de eigen gezondheid en kwaliteit van leven. We gaan in op cognitieve therapie, en daarbinnen specifiek op het gevolgenmodel. Op welke theorieën zijn deze behandelingen gebaseerd? Wat zijn de basisprincipes? Hoe werken deze therapieën? Wanneer kunnen ze worden ingezet?

Het beheersbaar houden van de kosten in de zorg staat hoog op de agenda van de overheid en de zorgverzekeraars. Dat betekent dat er wordt gekeken naar de verhouding tussen de effecten en de kosten van een behandeling. In week vier gaat het daarom over kosteneffectiviteit. Een ander onderwerp in deze week is de rol van non-specifieke factoren (zoals de duur van de therapie en de therapeutische relatie) bij psychologische behandelingen. Wat zijn deze factoren en hoe kan je ze beïnvloeden zodat een behandeling zo effectief mogelijk is?

In de vijfde week zijn we aanbeland bij meer intensievere behandelingen, zoals psychofarmacologie. Psychologen schrijven zelf geen pillen voor, maar het is belangrijk dat zij op de hoogte zijn van medische behandelmogelijkheden, hoe deze werken en wat de voor- en nadelen zijn.

Het practicum bestaat uit vier sessies, waarin je met je groep een (simulatie)patiënt met reuma en somberheidsklachten begeleidt. Je oefent o.a. het voeren van een intakegesprek en verschillende psychologische interventietechnieken. Op die manier doe je zoveel mogelijk ervaring op met technieken die je als therapeut kunt gebruiken. Ook heb je na afloop een overzicht van de verschillende fasen van het therapieproces (intake, behandelingsfase en afronding) en de specifieke eisen die elke fase stelt aan de therapeut.
Vanwege beperkte capaciteit kunnen maximaal 50 studenten deelnemen aan dit blok.

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>

column3: Dit keuzevak is bedoeld voor studenten psychologie die willen weten hoe psychologische behandelingen werken bij patiënten met lichamelijke klachten. Het is een introductie op behandelingen die door medisch psychologen kunnen worden ingezet. De medisch psycholoog werkt vanuit de visie dat somatische, psychologische en sociale aspecten bij elke aandoening een rol spelen. Vragen die o.a. aan bod komen zijn: Waarom zouden somatische patiënten eigenlijk gebaat kunnen zijn bij een psychologische behandeling? Voor welke patiënten is een psychologische behandeling geschikt (of noodzakelijk)? Welke vorm van psychologische behandeling biedt je een patiënt aan? Hoe motiveer je patiënten voor psychologische begeleiding? Wanneer kies je voor een psychologische behandeling en wanneer voor medicamenteuze therapie? Begin je standaard bij elke patiënt aan een eerstelijns psychologische behandeling, of kies je op basis van de kenmerken van de patiënt gelijk voor een tweede- of derdelijns zorgaanbod? Kan je nieuwe media en psychologische zorg combineren? Zo ja, hoe doe je dat? Werkt een psychologische behandeling eigenlijk wel? Zo ja, hoe werkt dat dan? Is het de theorie die ten grondslag ligt aan de therapie of is het de aandacht die je als cliënt krijgt van de therapeut? Hoe bepaal je of je behandeling heeft gewerkt? Na afloop van het blok heeft de student kennis opgedaan over indicatiecriteria voor verschillende psychologische behandelingen (voornamelijk psychologische interventies) die door medisch psychologen worden ingezet, de kenmerken en werkwijze van verschillende psychologische behandelingen en de effectieve bestanddelen ervan. Studenten kennen het principe van stepped-care en kunnen de voor- en nadelen daarvan uitleggen. Studenten zijn in staat om deze kennis toe te passen op praktische casuïstiek van patiënten met sterk uiteenlopende lichamelijke problemen die tijdens de onderwijsgroepen en practica aan bod komt.

Dit keuzevak is zowel interessant en geschikt voor studenten die de minor Medische Psychologie hebben gevolgd als voor studenten die (nog) weinig kennis hebben van het vakgebied van de medische psychologie.

column5: De student kan uitleggen wat de invloed van somatische aandoeningen kan zijn op het psychisch functioneren (en vice versa).
De student kan de stepped-care methodiek met de matched-care methodiek vergelijken.

De student kan aangeven welke verschillende behandelingen medisch psychologen kunnen gebruiken bij somatisch zieke patiënten met psychische problemen, zoals (online) zelfhulp, cognitieve gedragstherapie en psychofarmacologie.
De student kan aangeven wat de mogelijkheden en onmogelijkheden zijn van verschillende behandelingen die medisch psychologen kunnen inzetten bij somatisch zieke patiënten met psychische problemen
De student kan onderbouwen voor welke psychologische behandeling het beste gekozen kan worden bij een gefingeerde casus over een somatisch zieke patiënt met psychische problemen.
De student kan de basistechnieken van de cognitieve gedragstherapie benoemen en zelf toepassen bij een simulatiepatiënt.
De student kan benoemen en toelichten welke factoren bij psychologische behandelingen werkzaam zijn.

column2: </body>

</style>

column1: Psychophysiology assumes that cognitive, emotional, social and behavioral processes are mirrored in physiological processes in the human body. Electrophysiology focusses on electrophysiological processes, like activity in the brain, the heartbeat and muscle activity. It can be used to study all kind of mental events, like emotions and thoughts. With electroencephalography (EEG), we can visualize the activity in the brain, electrocardiography (ECG) investigates activity of the heart and electromyography (EMG) records activity of the muscles. In this practical training all three techniques will be covered. There will be lectures in which the theoretical background will be explained and there will be hands-on training sessions in which you will get experience with these techniques yourself.

column2: <title></title>

• you know how to measure EEG/ERP, ECG, and EMG, and you can explain the procedure.
• you know how to analyze EEG/ERP-data, and you can explain the procedure.
• you can write a report on a scientific electrophysiological experiment, according to a scientific format.

column1: <body>This course will provide a global outline of how the human body develops from a fertilised egg. From an embryological perspective, human prenatal development can be grossly divided into three periods, i.e. the early pre-embryonic period covering the first two weeks, the embryonic period from 2 to 8 weeks after conception, and the foetal period that extends from the 9<sup>th</sup> week to birth (usually at 38 weeks after conception). The early period is characterised by cell multiplication, implantation in the uterine wall, and the development of extra-embryonic tissues, such as the placenta and the amniotic membrane, which also arise from the fertilised egg. During this period, the cells that will give rise to the embryo remain undifferentiated. After two weeks of development, these undifferentiated cells are arranged in a disk-like structure. During the embryonic period this disk will transform into a small human body (~4 cm in length) with almost all organs and body parts present in a recognizable form. The foetal period is characterised by growth of the body and maturation of the organs. An important topic of this course will be the transformations during the 3<sup>rd</sup> and 4<sup>th</sup> week of development, when the early embryo transforms from a disk-like structure into a cylindrical embryo, in which most body parts and organs are formed in rudimentary form.</body>

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>

column3: After completing this course you will have basic knowledge of:

column5: Development of primordial germ cells, genital tract development and sexual differentiation
Early pre-implantation development
Sizes and gross appearance of the developing human body throughout pregnancy.

Development of the basic body plan, including the development of the major germinal layers (ectoderm, mesoderm, and endoderm), the development of the body axes (cranio-caudal, left-right, dorso-ventral), the role of key embryonic events, i.e. gastrulation, neurulation and embryonic folding, and the role of temporary embryonic structures such as the primitive streak, the notochord, neural crest, pharyngeal arches, somites, and lateral plate mesoderm

The role of signalling molecules, such as Sonic hedgehog, BMPs and Wnts, and transcription regulators such as the Hox family of proteins in the regulation of developmental processes such as the development of limbs and the vertebral column.
How abnormalities in embryonic signalling cascades may result in congenital malformations

column4: In this course we study emerging economies. This has become a popular theory since the end of the Cold War in the late 1980s. What exactly do we mean by emerging economies? Why and how do they develop? What are the effects of emerging economies on the global division of labour? This course takes a historical approach because the concept of emerging economies. Throughout world history we can discern the rise and decline of markets and economies. Before c. 1800 the economic centre of the world was firmly in Eastern Asia, but shifted to Western Europe and North America during the Industrial Revolution. We are now perhaps witnessing a new shift with the rise of the BRIC-countries: Brazil, Russia, India and China. These important economic processes also change the balance of economic and military power in the world and thus the system of international relations.

column2: </body>
<head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column3: - Students can define and discuss the concept of emerging economies.

column4: - Students can apply the concept of emerging economies to various historical cases.

column3: - Students can compare emerging economies in different regions of the world and through time.

column4: - Students can write and present a speech, review and newspaper article, organize a debate, and a case of an emerging economy.

column1: In this course, we will discuss how various empirical techniques are used to answer research questions in Personnel Economics, building on theoretical insights and econometric skills obtained in block 1. In particular, we discuss how to interpret findings in the light of both theory and empirical methods used.

column2: • Employee movement in and out of firm: screening, hiring, retention, quits;
• Monetary and non-monetary incentives;
• Supervision and monitoring;
• Teams and workforce diversity;
• Peer pressure and fairness.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/90455,2019,Empirical Research Methodology and Measurement,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,['dr. RP Rooderkerk'],,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

The course is structured around current and emerging themes and debates in the methodological literature. Current research routines and their alternatives will be discussed and critically assessed using literature in which competing approaches are presented and justified or criticized.
(a) Read literature on methodological debates and discuss its contents in class.
(b) Practice your understanding of this literature by means of assignments.

For each of the ten plenary sessions, there will be readings and an assignment. You will receive feedback on each assignment. Submission of assignments (before the stated deadline) and attendance at the sessions are mandatory.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>The goal of this course is to strengthen and deepen the understanding of the core methodological issues and choices in empirical research. The contents of this course comprise all phases of an empirical study, from the specification of its aim against the background of an evaluation of previous research, through case selection and measurement decisions, to the production of the study’s results, their interpretation and their reporting.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

This course deals with factors that influence learning, such as characteristics of the learner, characteristics of the learner's environment, and the learning process. Topics that we will focus on include individuals’ intellectual capacities and how intelligence contributes to learning, the influence of the family and the importance of upbringing in relation to learning, teachers’ role in the learning process and what he/she can do to motivate students. Moreover, we will learn how learners can influence their learning outcomes. For this, we will look at self-directed learning, which is an important learning skill, and physical movement and exercise as a means to support learning.

column1: Today, many Dutch law firms and companies expect their legal staff not only to be fluent in ordinary English, but familiar with legal English. Furthermore, the new Dutch court specializing in international commercial transactions, the ‘Netherlands Commercial Court’, conducts all its procedures and hearings in English.

The aim of this course is to familiarize students with the legal concepts behind English legal terminology. This will not only provide students with a better understanding of English legal texts, but will also give students the tools they need to be able to translate concepts from the Dutch legal system into English. With its emphasis on oral practice, the course will also help students to prepare for conducting legal discussions in English in their professional lives.

column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: <body>This course is intended for students who have studied law in a language other than English. The aim of this course is to familiarize students with the legal concepts behind English legal terminology. This will not only provide students with a better understanding of English legal texts, but will also give students the tools they need to be able to translate concepts from the Dutch legal systems into English. By also focusing on speaking about legal issues in English, it will help students to prepare for conducting legal discussions and negotiations in English in their professional lives.</body>

column1: This course is intended for students who have studied law in a language other than English. It is open to both Dutch and international students. This course will familiarize students with English legal terminology.

The aim of this English legal terminology course is two-fold: to help law students in their academic studies and to prepare them for professional life. However, it is not an ‘English for lawyers’ course. It is not a course dealing with English grammar. The focus of the course is on the legal concepts behind English legal terminology.

column1: <body>Why do students need to understand the context of Information Systems within enterprises?

column2: • Information Systems (IS) have enormous strategic value so when they are not working even for a short time, an organization cannot function;
• The Life Cycle Costs (acquisition, operation, security, and maintenance) of enterprise systems is considerable;

• It is therefore essential to manage information systems properly. The planning, organizing, implementing, operating, and controlling of the infrastructures and the organization's portfolio of applications must be done with great skill;
• To obtain awareness of different types of Information Systems and different roles that different systems play in organizations;
• To gain awareness and knowledge of ERP, CRM, SCM and E-Commerce;
• To be able to recognize opportunities that are enabled by information technology and to be able to decide to what extent information technology is needed within an organization.
• To understand critical issues in Information Systems, such as security, project risks and outsourcing of Information Systems. Be able to identify these issues and deal with them.

• The course also helps students digest why most ERP systems do not live up to its acronym of planning resources for the enterprise. Students should be able to critically evaluate the following questions:
• What is ERP? What is EIS? How do People and Process come into Technology?
• What are the similarities and differences between ERP and EIS?
• How do Enterprise Systems affect Accountants and Economists?
• How can economic theory help explain the effects of information technology on organizations and value chains?
• What benefits have been realized by certain companies by implementing Information Technology?
• How can information technology be an enabler but also be an inhibitor for realizing an organization its strategy?
• What are advantages and disadvantages from new technologies as Big Data and Blockchain
<title></title>

• Students are able to analyse and identify different situations in which technology is able to help an organization succeed in its goals.
• Students are able to use different theories to explain how the use of technology may affect organisations.
• Students are able to critically analyse and report on research findings from a project they perform in a logical and consistent way.
• Students are able to present their research essay as well as answer critical questions about this essay in a convincing manner.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/89117,2019,Entrepreneurial Skillset,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,['dr. MN Cholakova'],,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Running a start-up requires operating under high uncertainty and navigating well through often chaotic, confusing information and experiences. In this course, we will focus on the customer development process, after an opportunity has been identified, and address a set of skills that can help early-stage entrepreneurs to manage their ventures more effectively. In particular, we will discuss different leadership styles and decision making approaches and explore how these can affect the performance, motivation and culture of the members of a new venture. We will further focus on strategies for making good decisions and discuss ways to avoid common mistakes and biases throughout the customer development journey. Being an effective entrepreneur and leader will also require learning how to develop empathy and to engage effectively with your customer, by acquiring strong interviewing techniques. As an entrepreneur, you would also often need to handle difficult conversations and we will further identify a set of techniques for effective conflict resolution, as well as a range of influence tactics and mechanisms that can be applied in your start-up and work relationships. In addition, we will discuss different negotiation styles and learn how best to align individuals’ goals, interests and values with those of the organization. The overall aim of the course is to provide practical knowledge and skills that future entrepreneurs can apply when developing, testing and validating their hypotheses about a business opportunity.
Course Format – Action Learning and Reflective Exercises

The teaching philosophy for this course is based on action learning and reflection. Students are thus expected to develop a hands-on approach to the themes covered in the course. Active class participation is highly recommended as the lectures are intended to offer practical insight and an opportunity to directly apply the new skills.

Learning from the course is greatly enhanced when everyone is able to contribute and collectively share knowledge and experience with the different topics.  It is your responsibility to come to class fully prepared. To facilitate your learning, you are expected to contribute to class discussions, ask questions, express opinions, draw linkages among cases and theories, and develop new ideas.

We will selectively discuss key constructs and ideas from each class’ reading list and, where applicable, the respective case assignment. The purpose of this course is to help you develop some of the skills that we will address in each session, backed by a set of readings and applied examples from the cases. This means that in class, we will largely try to focus on applying the theory by means of engaging you in simulations, role plays, team exercises, etc. Hence, it is your responsibility to have prepared the readings and worked through the cases, as they will not necessarily be discussed in each class in a step-by-step fashion. Your knowledge of the relevant literature will be evaluated based on your reflective assignments and team projects.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: <li>
Understand the dynamics of the entrepreneurial process and learn best practices for customer development.
<li>
Recognize and practice different strategies for effective decision making and identify the factors and specific approaches that can help you make better decisions for your start-up.
<li>
Gain insight into how to develop empathy and apply it into your customer development process.
<li>
Practice and learn a set of different leadership characteristics and styles and analyze how each can have a distinct impact on start-up teams’ motivation, commitment, and culture.
<li>
Analyze and apply a set of negotiation techniques and learn how to apply them in order to improve your start-up’s outcomes.
<li>
Identify the right balance of roles, rewards and relationships when managing your team.
<li>
Learn how to deal with conflict and manage difficult employees by applying a set of conflict resolution techniques.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/88574,2019,Entrepreneurial challenge,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,"['dr. FPH Jaspers', 'M Bax']",,"Inhoud

column2: <title></title>
<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: The course Entrepreneurial Challenge is an intensive module. You will explore and experience what it entails to start a new and ambitious company. You will come to understand that not only existing businesses, but also new businesses require management. As you are enrolled in the Master in Management program, it is important to understand that without businesses there is nothing to manage, and without entrepreneurs there would be (and will be) no businesses. Furthermore, many RSM graduates will – at some stage in their career – consider entrepreneurship as a serious career opportunity.

In line with RSM’s mission statement we will focus on social entrepreneurship, supporting one of the SDG’s which will be introduced elaborately. The course contains a concise introduction to the domain of social entrepreneurship theory and research. To apply the key concepts and tools in a real-life setting, teams will develop and revise their own start-up opportunities and explore viable business models in the field of social entrepreneurship. Entrepreneurship is about turning unmet needs and unsolved problems into viable economic activity. The essence of entrepreneurship has been described as ‘the pursuit of opportunity without regard to the resources currently controlled.’ Entrepreneurship starts with the discovery of promising opportunities. Understanding the origins of such opportunities is key for start-up entrepreneurs and existing companies alike to develop business models that will effectively create and capture value from the identified opportunities. Entrepreneurship is not just a process, but also a mindset. In this module you develop that mindset by exploring the first stages of the process: the identification and evaluation of opportunities and the search for viable business models.

The course requires that all students actively participate in the classes. In addition, we expect the students to spend additional time per day on class preparation by reading the literature and doing project work. This course is a crash course into the (theoretical) foundations of entrepreneurship and a pressure cooker module for developing a business case and presenting it in front of a jury; both of them require your full dedication.

The sessions in this module will differ in nature, ranging from student presentations, to workshops, to feedback sessions. During these meetings, a proactive and constructive atmosphere will be stimulated: a collaborative, open approach is needed to help each other and to learn from each other. The instructor in this course will serve primarily as a coach, rather than as a teacher. His main concern is to guide the group and the teams through the necessary thought and work processes.
Attendance of all university sessions is compulsory

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: • You will come to understand that new venture creation is a process to systematically turn business model assumptions into knowledge, and that this learning process typically involves business model change.

• You will come to understand the complexity of the new venture creation process, i.e. you will be able to explain and illustrate that its key steps, activities and challenges are highly interrelated, interdisciplinary, unpredictable, heterogeneous, and iterative.
• You will develop the capability to construct, evaluate, and refine business models for new ventures.
• You will develop the capability to set-up effective and efficient research designs to turn critical assumptions into knowledge.
• You will develop the capability to document your business modelling process concisely, with clarity, logical flow, and coherence.

• You will develop the capability to discuss and present your new venture creation process in a variety of contexts, i.e. in your multidisciplinary student team, during the plenary workshops, in a feedback session with startup coaches and entrepreneurs, and in front of an expert panel at the final presentation session.

column1: The objective of this course is to provide students with a state-of-the-art understanding of the valuation of small and mid-cap public and private firms, and the economics of contracts as it applies to entrepreneurship and new venture finance. Entrepreneurship concerns the undertaking of new business ventures. We will analyse the unique financial issues relating to entrepreneurial firms and to develop a set of skills that has wide applications for such situations. Specific topics will include: start-up ventures; financial management of rapidly growing firms; deal structuring; valuation; initial public offerings; the decision to harvest; and leveraged/ management buyouts. We will discuss the various sources of capital for entrepreneurial firms. These sources include venture capital, commercial banks and crowd funding. The decisions of firms at various phases of their life cycle will be examined and the advantages and disadvantages of various sources of financing will be compared. Analytical tools will be introduced and utilized. Financial analysis, various valuation methods, negotiations, and deal structuring are examined in the context of entrepreneurial firms. This course is aimed at students who plan to start, acquire, finance or work for entrepreneurial, fast-growing businesses. It will also be useful for students who plan to join venture capital/private equity firms and investment banks. The course aims at instructing the student in how “real world” professional investors and corporate managers operate to create wealth from entrepreneurial activity.</body>

column1: After having followed this course, students are among others able to understand how to value a start-up firm, how contracts used in new venture finance shape incentives, how deals are structured, how to finance young start-up companies, how private equity works in creating value in start-ups, buyouts and growth financing and how to decide when to exit investments. Students are also able to appraise and construct a valuation for a start-up company, compare and select the different sources of financing and connect theory and practice.

If you want to know more about developing a business model for a startup and/or setting up your own venture, the Entrepreneurial Lab course is for you. Within an intense and hand-on experiential approach, the Entrepreneurial Lab course allows you exploring a business opportunity with your team and testing its potential value.

This course provides advanced master students with a practical, yet rigorous understanding of the role, the analytics, and the process of business planning that leads to the successful creation of new ventures. We bring in guest lecturers and practitioners to provide lectures and workshops. Above all, students will be responsible to develop their own professional networks. As it’s a hands-on course, you will learn about business modelling, how to refine opportunities, analyse feasibility, financial planning, and organisational implementation. You will write a weekly blog and a business report and pitch your idea to a jury of experts. In previous years our students launched successful new businesses, including Senz Umbrellas, Symbid and Yoursurprise.com.

column2: The major part of this Minor is the Core Module where you learn how to get started and develop entrepreneurial skills (such as pitching, financial bootstrapping and design thinking). Next to the Core Module, students choose one out of two elective modules that help them to develop their entrepreneurial knowledge and skills in a specific area: Entrepreneurial Marketing or Entrepreneurial Finance. These electives focus on (1) marketing challenges and how entrepreneurs with limited budgets reach, communicate and co-develop with their customers; and (2) unique financial issues related to entrepreneurial firms and the (dis)advantages of various sources of financing, respectively.

column1: In this course we will introduce entrepreneurship as an academic discipline and we will discuss some important aspects of starting a new venture. This course contains a concise introduction to the domain of entrepreneurship theory and practice. Entrepreneurship is all about identifying opportunities and pursuing them. Understanding the origins of such opportunities is key for entrepreneurs and existing companies alike in order to develop business models that will effectively create and capture value. In this course students will focus on three views of entrepreneurship theory: entrepreneurship, corporate entrepreneurship and social entrepreneurship. Entrepreneurship is not just a process but also a mind-set; it is behaviour.  Students will also develop that mind-set by exploring the first stages of entrepreneurial process: the identification and evaluation of opportunities and the search for viable business models. This course is a crash course in the (theoretical) foundations of entrepreneurship and a pressure cooker module for developing a business case and presenting it in front of a jury.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>After the course, students are able to:

column2: • Explain what entrepreneurship is, what its central elements are, and why entrepreneurship is crucial for our economy and society;
• Explain the difference between entrepreneurship and management in general, and between entrepreneurship, intrapreneurship and social entrepreneurship in particular.
• Develop a business model by applying the principles of the lean startup method.
• Explain how new ventures emerge and develop.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/87179,2019,Entrepreneurship in Media and Business,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,"['PM Leendertse, MA']",,"Inhoud

column1: During this course we will address the role of entrepreneurship within media markets. We will look at this issue from two angles: entrepreneurship from the perspective of the challenger start-up company and entrepreneurship within existing media firms. We will discuss literature on entrepreneurship and business model innovation and apply these insights to media related case studies. Furthermore, we will discuss how entrepreneurial principles are applied to social media endeavors. We will address questions such as: how to identify new market or social opportunities,  how to find competitive advantage in a media market, how to move from idea to execution and how to scale up and manage growth.

In line with the entrepreneurial focus of this course, students are required to write a business plan for a media-related startup and develop a new value proposition for an existing company. During this process students will experience the valuable contribution of scientific inquiry and insights for the development of new products and services. Students are also required to pitch their buisness idea and will receive presentation training during the course.

As entrepreneurship is the theme of the course, we will invite several professionals from the media industry to discuss their entrepreneurial endeavors. We will also try to arrange having company visits (the dates for these visits might be at a different time than regular classes). Students are also encouraged to organize thes themselves.
Note: The minimum number of participants is 6, the maximum number is 25. Students of the MA programme in Media & Business take priority over other students.

column2: <title></title>
<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: Entering the 21st century, climate change, globalization, inequality, and rural-to-urban migration have created conditions conducive to emerging infectious diseases and food production challenges. Epidemics and famine are yet to be consigned to the past, and this is worrying given that the World Health Organization has expressed concerns that the social and economic impact of both can be massive. However, measuring their effects is not straightforward. Can history provide new insights by offering a temporal perspective?

By comparing traumatic events such as Great European Famine of 1315-17, the ‘Columbian Exchange’ diseases of American colonization, the worldwide influenza pandemic of 1918-20, and the Great Leap Forward Famine in China of 1958-62, can we understand more about diseases today such as Ebola or famines in East Africa, Syria and Yemen? Although the past may be a ‘foreign country’, we shall see that there are many points of continuity and similarity.

Students will learn the causes and characteristics of epidemics and famines, and their effects on development and welfare, social (dis)order, gender inequalities, public health, and their relationship with climate change. We also consider how epidemics and famines have been represented and remembered by surviving generations, and consider controversies over ‘who is to blame’.

column2: <title></title>

</style>

column1: 1. Students will explain the causes, characteristics and consequences of epidemic diseases and famines throughout history.
2. Students will recognize that the outcomes from epidemics and famines could be very different across time, region, and outbreak, and offer explanations.
3. Students will draw links between the pre-industrial past, the recent past, and contemporary developments, and show the value of a historical approach to epidemics and famines.

column1: Land governance is about the political economy of land, and equitable land governance focuses on the notion of equity and sustainability and the need for designing land policies, initiatives and instruments that can help to address market failure and protect the environment as well as vulnerable members of society from the impacts of unequitable markets.

“An understanding of land issues from a governance and political economy perspective can  be  derived  through  a  three  part  framework  that  (i)  analyzes  the  broad  country  context, the types of tenure that exist, the operation of land markets and the institutions (rules  and  structures)  that  regulate  both  tenure  and  markets;  (ii)  examines how a governance  and  political  economy  perspective  can  be  applied  to  a  specific  land  issue or  reform  context,  with  emphasis  on  clarifying  stakeholders,  interests,  influence,  institutions and relationships; and (iii) explores how to manage a reform process.” Palmer, D., Fricska, S. & Wehrmann, B. 2009
In the RW, students will split up into working groups that correspond to the three thematic clusters of the ULG specialization.
Students can develop their thesis proposals in accordance to the ULG clusters depicted below:

EULG consist of two research workshops and four colloquia. The colloquia will enable students to obtain feedback on their research from IHS staff and their peers in the UMD program. Each colloquium is connected to chapters of the thesis.

The first research workshop will focus on the development of conceptual frameworks based on theoretical discussions on the selected topic of students. Students will be exposed to literature on: land rights and the rule of law; land markets and finance; and land, water and natural resources. The theories reviewed will be the underpinning of their thesis proposals and analysis.
Output: At the end of RW 1, students should have completed their theoretical chapters.

The second research workshop is aimed at equipping EULG students with the techniques needed to conduct their fieldwork. It supports students in the operationalization of their variables and in collecting the right type of data needed to carry out their analysis.
Output: At the end of RW 2, students should have completed their research proposals.

column1: The research workshop aims to support students in investigating and analysing the ways in which urban land, water and natural resources are governed through research. At the end of the research workshop, students should be able to write their research proposal (introduction, literature review and methodology chapters) on equitable urban land governance, considering in detail the notions of equity and sustainability—and the policy and institutional implications of these approaches.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/87046,2019,Erasmus and Grotius on Islam and Judaism,Engels,"Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,['prof.dr. E Rabbie'],,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Although Desiderius Erasmus (Rotterdam, 1466 [?] – Basel, 1536) as a humanist and student of religion was primarily and almost exclusively interested in Christianity, and thus never systematically occupied himself with the two other monotheistic religions that were known to him, Judaism and Islam, there is a fairly large number of passages in his works that deal critically with these two religions. After a short introduction on Erasmus’ life and works, the main attention during this course will be focused on reading a selection of relevant original texts from Erasmus’ works (in English translation).

Almost exactly one century after Erasmus, another Dutch humanist, Hugo Grotius (Delft, 1583 – Rostock, 1645) , called ‘the second Erasmus’ by some of his contemporaries, wrote a defense of Christian religion (On the Truth of Chistian Religion, 1627), in which he attempted a systematical ‘refutation’ of both Judaism and Islam. The second half of the course– again, after a general introduction to the author – will be devoted to a study of this book.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

The student will become familiar with two important figures of 16th and 17th centuries European Christian humanism, Erasmus and Grotius, with special emphasis on their views of Islam and Judaism. The student will also become familiar with some of the key texts of both scholars on this subject (in English translation), thus learning to interpret an ancient text in its historical context.

column1: We will discuss four key contemporary examples in practical philosophy of pressing social, political and cultural issues, or ‘challenges’. We will explore their implications on both the individual and on the collective level. The four challenges are: 1) Enlightenment as emancipation: a blessing or a burden? The pressures of modern living. Emancipation frees us from many burdens, but now creates new and unexpected ones. 2) Democracy: do we need more, or less? Government and citizens seem deadlocked in a struggle for more and better democracy. Can democracy deliver on its promises – and can the citizens keep up? 3) Environment: how do we configure individual and collective responsibility to constrain climate chaos? From an environmental justice perspective, those worst hit by environmental harms are in the least political and social positions to challenge their generating structures. 4) Public health: What is the proper relationship between looking out for the health of people versus corporate power to advertise harmful products? With rising medical costs, how to distribute scarce resources? What is the role of prevention?
This course aims to promote reflection on these contemporary issues and their linkages through exploring various philosophical responses and dilemmas.

column1: This upper-division undergraduate course studies fundamental philosophical problems at the intersection of ethics and economics. It provides students with the skills to critically evaluate economic arguments, to connect these arguments with contemporary moral theories, and to apply these theories to pervasive social problems.</body>

column2: <title></title>
<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: By the end of the course, students should be able to:

1. define and elaborate on core concepts in economics (hedonic vs. preferentialist utility, Pareto improvements, weak vs. strong sustainability, contested exchange) and ethics (side-constraints, moral incentives, rule vs. act utilitarianism, lax vs. strong difference principle, workplace democracy).
2. critically assess economic aspects of property rights, market exchange, gender inequality, and environmental degradation in light of the main moral theories.
3. assess these theories themselves, in terms of their coherence, cogency, and relevance.</body>
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/89562,2019,Ethics and Economics,Engels,Erasmus School of Philosophy,,['dr. CB Binder'],,Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>This graduate course offers a profound examination of ethics and economics in theory and practice. Firstly, we will study some key concepts and values in economics. What is a market, and what are the virtues and moral limits of markets? What are property rights, and what is their moral relevance? What are the values usually invoked to defend markets? How are markets taken to promote efficiency, freedom and human well-being respectively? Secondly, we will analyze some substantive normative positions on economic questions, such as those held by right-libertarians, left-libertarians or Marxists. This will also allow us to study different ethical foundations that have been offered for different economic systems, such as varieties of capitalism and socialism. In a third step we explore the moral limits of markets and discuss possibly alternative economic systems. Among others, we discuss some specific policy proposals related to debates about ethical problems of our current economic system, such as basic income as a response to increasing material inequality.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>The main objective of this course is twofold. Firstly, students acquire an understanding of the relationship between ethics and economics in terms of its historical development, as well as in terms of its role in the contemporary discipline of economics, as well as the economy. Secondly, students learn to critically assess the positions in the field and further develop their oral and written argumentation skills.

column2: • By the end of this course you should have a good overview of recent work done in the field of economics ethics. You will have studied work by the main contemporary philosophers as well as the most important discussions and issues in this field.
• You will be equipped to do research (e.g. for a Master’s dissertation) on questions of economic ethics, both theoretical/conceptual as well as applied questions.

• This course will help you to improve your knowledge of methods and styles of arguments in analytical moral philosophy (esp. ethics/normative political philosophy) – which can also be useful for other streams within analytical moral philosophy.

• You will be able to practice, refine and further develop your writing and argumentation skills for analytical practical philosophy. This will be a special focus of this course, since you will receive detailed and extensive individual feedback on your written pieces of work.
• You will be able to practice, refine and further develop your oral argumentation and presentation skills in moral philosophy, through participating in the class discussions.
• You will be able to learn/practice/rehearse some basic skills related to literature searching and use of libraries and bibliographical search methods.

E.M. Bunnik', 'dr. L.L.E. Bolt', 'dr. S. van de Vathorst', ""H. Ismaili M'hamdi"", 'I. Tuink - Brinkman', 'J. Specker', 'M. Smedinga', 'mr. J.G.M. Aartsen', 'N. Aarts, MSc', 'prof. dr. I.D. de Beaufort', 'prof. dr. M.H.N. Schermer', 'Y.H. Stol']",,
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/89590,2019,"Ethiek, rationaliteit en emotie I",Nederlands,Erasmus School of Philosophy,,"['dr. JP Kloeg', 'dr. PJJ Delaere']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Welke rol spelen emoties in de morele oordeelsvorming van mensen? Zijn emoties constitutief voor de morele positie die mensen innemen of zijn het stoorzenders die een redelijke oordeelsvorming in de weg staan? En: wat zijn emoties? Zijn emoties louter gevoelens en is een moreel oordeel daarom altijd de expressie van een bepaald gevoel? Of zijn emoties ook te beschouwen als cognitieve mentale toestanden die ons informatie verschaffen over onszelf en over de wereld om ons heen? Ter beantwoording van deze vragen zullen we in deze cursus niet alleen de meest actuele moraalfilosofische debatten over ethiek, rationaliteit en emoties bespreken, maar ook te rade gaan bij het hedendaagse moraalwetenschappelijke onderzoek naar de oorsprong en aard van emoties en naar de invloed van emoties bij oordeelsvorming (o.m. werk van Frans de Waal, Jonathan Haidt en Antonio Damasio). We zullen nadenken over de lichamelijke basis van gevoelens en emoties en dit verbinden met cognitief psychologisch onderzoek naar de onmisbare (en soms misleidende) rol van emoties in het redeneren en het vormen van een standpunt. Vervolgens zullen we discussiëren over wat dit betekent voor de aard en de betrouwbaarheid van evaluatieve oordelen. Een morele stellingname is meer dan de expressie van een gevoel. Maar in welke zin is het meer en anders?

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Inzicht verkrijgen in de belangrijkste hedendaagse moraalfilosofische en moraalwetenschappelijke visies en debatten over de aard van emoties en over de rol van emoties en redenen in morele oordeelsvorming; het op basis van dit inzicht ontwikkelen van een eigen standpunt ten aanzien van enkele cruciale kwesties in de morele psychologie en meta-ethiek.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/86985,2019,Ethnographic Research into Culture Participation,Engels,"Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,['prof.dr. EH Bisschop Boele'],,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Central in the course is the discussion of two strands of literature. The first strand will focus on the elements of ethnographic research. We will read and discuss literature on data collection, data analysis, theoretical backgrounds (the interpretive research traditions, practice theory), and specific ethnographic/ethnography-related traditions such as auto-ethnography or grounded theory. This will be combined with the reading of examples of ethnographic research into culture participation. During the course, specific assignments will be given to practice the various elements of ethnographic research. In the meetings, students will be involved in active discussion as well as practical exercises in, e.g., interviewing and the open coding of ethnographic data. Students carry out a small ethnographic research project of their own choice, which is prepared through various assignments and which will be reported upon in the final essay. The course will provide a firm introduction into the topic and a sound basis for those who wish to carry out ethnographic or ethnograpically inspired research in the future.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

This course will provide students with an introductory but thorough understanding of ethnographic research into culture participation. Students will read and discuss key literature on the theoretical backgrounds and methodological issues of ethnographic research. This will be combined with a discussion of examples of ethnographic research into cultural participation. Students will be asked to carry out and report on individual research activities connected to the three main data sources in ethnography (observation, interview, study of documents/artefacts); this will feed into their final assignment, which will be the production of an essay based on the analysis of own empirical data.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/87039,2019,Europe in a Globalizing World: Migration, Citizenship and Identity","Engels, Nederlands","Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,"['dr. CLA Willemse', 'G van Campenhout, MSc', 'prof.dr. G Oonk']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Which passport is the most accepted passport around the world and why is this (un)fair? How many generations does it take for a settler and his family to become 'native'? What is the potential of global citizenship in relation to patriotic realities? These are just some of the pressing questions which are fully explored in this course on Global Migration, Citizenship and Identity. Migration and ethnic minorities have always challenged the ‘nation’ in the Nation State. In this series of lectures we will discuss the development of cosmopolitan citizenship and its discontents. We will take examples from Europe, the US as well South Africa, Japan, Brazil and India. We discuss issues as slavery and citizenship, birth right lottery, paper citizens, multiple passports and loyalties. Global migration has forced us to re-think the construction of the nation state. States increasingly compete with each other for international prestige and economic development. They wish to attract skilled laborers (including sportsmen and women and scientist) and investors or rich consumers. In addition, however, especially western welfare states wish to restrict migration from poor countries to protect the welfare levels of its citizens. Cosmopolitism may be seen as an asset, a challenge and a burden.

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>

column4: Students study three different perspectives on migration and citizenship; (1) Egalitarian liberalism, (2) Communitarian and (3) libertarian perspectives. With these three perspectives in mind they learn how to debate national self-determination, migration and multiculturalism and global distributive justice and migration. By the end of the course they are able to write a critical review of an academic monograph on migration, citizenship and identity.

column2: </body>

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/86328,2019,Europe in the World,Engels,Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences,,['prof.dr. M Onderco'],,Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Europe in the World is a Master course for students in the International Public Management and Policy program. This course aims at developing students’ understanding of the activities of the European Union in the world. By the end of the course, the students will be able to understand and theoretically explain the EU’s external action. They will appreciate the difficulties of EU’s foreign action, and will be able to critically appraise the EU’s foreign policy. Students will have improved soft and transferrable skills.

Students in this course will be expected to have covered the basics of international relations theory. This can be done by having passed the course Global Governance in the IMP program, or an alternative program elsewhere (recognized at the discretion of the instructor).

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>By the end of the class, the students will be able to

column2: • Illustrate and explain areas of EU’s activity in the world
• Compare different means of EU’s foreign affairs activity
• Contrast EU’s approaches in different areas of foreign policy
• Critically evaluate EU’s efficiency in global governance and foreign affairs

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/89885,2019,European Integration: An Interdisciplinary Perspective,Engels,Erasmus University College,,['dr. CDC van der Veeke', 'dr. CWA van Wijnbergen', 'dr. JP Kloeg', 'dr. T Ertuna Lagrand, LL.M', 'PK Livaha, LLM']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

The end of WWII engendered the world’s most far-reaching experiment in international cooperation between sovereign nation states.  European countries embarked on a process of integration which has brought them peace, stability and prosperity. Yet, on the European Union’s 60th anniversary, celebrations are noticeably muted with citizens’ support for European integration flagging.  How come?

This course explores the historical, political, and economic background to European integration.  It will elucidate the EU’s unique origins, institutions and competences, and debate its place in the world and its relationship to member states.  The course sets out to provide the theoretical foundations to critically discuss questions on EU governance, key policy areas, crises and reforms, and to contemplate the EU’s future.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>After completing the course, you should be able to:

column2: • Understand the origins and evolution of European integration;
• Assess the political and economic motives of member states to join the European Union;

• Explain the necessary conditions for the transition from constitutional right to international right, as stated by Immanuel Kant in Toward Perpetual Peace (1795), and use this to evaluate the feasibility of the idea of a politically integrated Europe;
• Analyze and reproduce the arguments of Hegel against Kant's idea of global/European perpetual peace;
• Evaluate theories on European integration;
• Understand the institutional structure and the legal system of the EU, as well as its competences and the limitations thereof;
• Understand the economics behind monetary integration and assess the recent crisis in the Eurozone and potential solutions;
• Apply concepts of sovereignty to the EU in keeping with the latter's political form;
• Examine the European Union’s relations with the outside world;
• Articulate an informed view about current debates on the EU.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/88268,2019,European Law: Justice and Home Affairs,Engels,Erasmus School of Law,,['dr. F Coman Kund', 'mr. RM Klein Entink', 'N Pouls, LL.M', 'prof.dr. R Repasi', 'RI Timmerman, MA', 'SD Kruit, MSc', 'SR Matthijsse, MSc', 'TP Poot, LL.M']",,
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/87836,2019,European Private International Law,Engels,Erasmus School of Law,,"['dr. EA Ontanu', 'dr. J Constantino Chagas Lessa']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

The globalisation of trade has led to an increase of transnational relations and situations that can require the application of different sets of rules in a cross-border context. For instance, an English company concludes a sales contract with a French company; an agent settled in the Netherlands represents a United States-based company in several European countries; a German consumer buys goods from a Swiss company over the internet; a semi-finished product manufactured in Spain causes damages in further production chain in Poland.

International legal practice is increasingly confronted with questions of private international (including procedural) law. The substantial diversity of jurisdiction and procedure rules, and the lack of harmonisation may increase legal uncertainty and ineffective adjudication.

This course focuses on the general concepts of private international law and the application of private international law. Particular attention is given to private international law at European Union level and to related international conventions. Where relevant, attention will be paid to comparative aspects, for example common law jurisdiction vs. civil law jurisdiction.

The instruments to be discussed include those dealing with international jurisdiction, recognition and enforcement, evidence, service of documents, harmonised European procedures (i.e. European Order for Payment, European Small Claims, European Account Preservation Order), insolvency, and the applicable law to (commercial) contracts and torts.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<div>A student who has successfully completed this course should:

column2: • identify the sources of private international law;
• assess the importance and problems of harmonisation of private international law at European level, and to some extent at international level;
• understand general concepts of international jurisdiction, including lis pendens and forum non conveniens, forum shopping, choice of forum, jurisdiction in personam, and jurisdiction in rem;
• understand the concepts of recognition and enforcement, including reciprocity, exequatur, free movement of judgments, and grounds of refusal;
• understand general concepts and principles of conflicts of laws, including party autonomy, connecting factors, public policy, and overriding mandatory rules;
• compare the process of service of documents under the European Service Regulation and the Hague Service Convention, and apply the European Service Regulation;
• compare the process of obtaining evidence under the European Evidence Regulation and the Hague Evidence Convention, and apply the European Evidence Regulation;
• assess the position of weaker parties in European Private International Law;
• have a basic understanding of the European uniform procedures;
• apply European jurisdiction rules to concrete civil and commercial matters;
• determine how a concrete judgment regarding civil and commercial matters given in a Member State can be recognised and enforced in another Member State;
• determine on the basis of European legislation in a concrete case which law applies to commercial or civil relationship or claim;
• describe the interplay between the UN Convention of International Sales of Goods and Rome I Regulation;

• understand the concept of centre of main interest (COMI), determine jurisdiction and the applicable law in insolvency proceedings, the recognition and enforcement of opening of insolvency proceedings;
• analyse the relationship between European Private International Law and third states.

column1: The course offers and introduction to the European Union Law. It provides insights into: a) the evolution of the European Union and the sources of EU law; b) EU institutions; c) the decision making process of the EU; d) the relationship between EU law and the legal systems of the EU Member States; e) the internal market All subjects within the course are approached from a point of view which enables the students to grasp the evolution of European integration. The course intends to embed law related questions into the wider political, social and economic EU-context, without leaving out the developments and discussions as to the future of the European Union.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
On completion of this course, the student will be able to:

column2: • Understand the institutional structure and the legal system of the EU, as well as its competences and the limitations thereof,
• Understand the foundations of EU Single Market Law, EU Competition Law, EU Citizenship, principle of Equal Treatment and Human Rights within the EU, and EU Migration Law,
• Distinguish the legal issues embedded in news items, literature etc.
• Point to the legal and institutional ways of solving basic legal problems/cases

column1: In recent decades, there has been a rapidly increasing influence of European Union law on more and more areas of national law. Because of this development, people often speak of the progressive 'Europeanization' of different parts of the national legal systems of the Member States of the EU. Virtually all jurisdictions are affected by EU law, which means that the developments in EU law have a major impact not only on the functioning of the national legal jurisdiction and judicial organization, but also on the daily lives of ordinary citizens.

Building on the students’ existing knowledge about the basic principles of EU law and the institutional framework of the EU, the second-year course ‘European Union Law’ goes beyond the basics of the EU’s construct. In particular, the course focuses on the substantive law of the EU. Students will gain an understanding of the internal market and the four fundamental freedoms, the system of legal protection in the EU, EU competition law, as well as Brexit.

column1: Upon completion of this course, students will not only be able to understand the foundations and background of EU law, but will also be able to find, understand, analyze, interpret, critique, and apply the (primary and secondary) rules on legal protection, the four freedoms of the internal market, and EU competition law in the EU to case studies. In addition, student will also be able to find, analyze and apply the relevant case law of the ECJ to a case study.

column1: <body>This course analyses the European Union as a political system. Rather than just describing the various political actors and formal and informal decision-making procedures, the course aims at a higher level of understanding by applying theories based on institutional rational choice to the various facets of the EU. The basic idea is that political outcomes are the result of actor preferences and institutions (as rules of the game). Equipped with this approach we will analyse among other things, executive politics, legislative politics, judicial politics, interest group politics, and policy making in a variety of areas.</body>

column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: <body>After completion of this course, students are able to:

column2: • describe the composition, internal structure and formal decision-making role of EU actors such as the European Commission and the European Parliament;
• describe the main problems and dynamics of EU policy-making concerning regulatory policies, expenditure policies, and interior policies;

• define central concepts of rational choice-informed political science theories, such as principal agent theories and coalition-formation theory and to describe the assumptions and hypotheses of these theories;

• apply rational-choice informed political science theories to executive politics, legislative politics, judicial politics, interest groups politics, regulatory policies, expenditure policies and interior policies;
• synthesize information about changes in the actor's environment, its effects of actor preferences and changing institutions to predict policy change;
• effectively communicate orally about case study findings.

column1: Een van de redenen voor de Europese toenadering en de totstandkoming van het Verdrag betreffende (de werking van) de Europese Unie is het streven van de lidstaten om te komen tot een interne, markt zonder fiscale belemmeringen, beperkingen of distorsies. Hierdoor moeten onder andere ondernemingen in staat worden gesteld om zich beter aan te passen aan de interne markt, hun productiviteit te vergroten en hun concurrentiepositie op de internationale markt te versterken. Tijdens dit vak wordt geanalyseerd hoe lidstaten deze economische voorspoed kunnen bereiken zonder oneerlijke fiscale concurrentie. Naast de positieve Europese integratie - de regelgeving - wordt ruimschoots aandacht besteed aan de negatieve integratie, de arresten die door het Hof van Justitie worden gewezen.
Het vak bevat o.a. de volgende onderwerpen:

column2: • Begrippenapparaat + interpretatiemethoden
• Beginselen van het Europees recht
• Bespreking van de verkeersvrijheden in het VwEU
• Staatssteun in het VwEU
• Formeelrechtelijke aspecten van het EU-recht
• Fiscale richtlijnen van de EU
• Wisselwerking tussen EU-recht en nationaal fiscaal recht

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: • Inzicht verwerven in de algemene beginselen van het EU belastingrecht en in het bijzonder het beslisschema van het Hof van Justitie.
• De vaardigheid ontwikkelen om aan de hand van het EU belastingrecht nationaalrechtelijke belastingregels te toetsen op hun aanvaardbaarheid.
• Het kritische vermogen ontwikkelen om op zelfstandige wijze naar nationaalrechtelijke belastingregels te kijken.

column1: De rol en positie van de Europese unie staan volop in de aandacht. Burgers, bedrijven en overheden hebben in tal van opzichten met Europees beleid te maken. Het functioneren van ons land en van ons openbaar bestuur wordt sterk door ons lidmaatschap van de Europese Unie beïnvloedt. Tegelijkertijd staat de positie van Europese Unie onder druk en is de toekomst van de ontwikkeling van de Europese Unie onzeker.

Juist in dit tijdsgewricht is kennis van de wordingsgeschiedenis en het functioneren van de Europese Unie van groot belang. Allereerst om de aard van de zich voordoende ontwikkelingen en hun implicaties te kunnen begrijpen. Maar ook omdat bestuurskundigen functioneren in een bestel waarin de EU alom aanwezig is. De Europese integratie heeft ertoe geleid dat het functioneren van het openbaar bestuur op lokale, regionale en nationale bestuurslagen sterk met ontwikkelingen op Europees niveau samenhangen. Daarbij komt dat de EU niet los van ontwikkelingen op andere bestuurlijke niveaus staat, maar dat deze niveaus deel uit maken van de Europese Unie en dat, gegeven het grensoverschrijdende karakter van veel problemen en taken, deze niet simpel meer op lokaal of nationaal niveau afgehandeld kunnen worden. Tegelijkertijd doen nationale, regionale en lokale verschillen ertoe en is de mate waarin Europa erin slaagt daarmee om te gaan in toenemende mate bepalend is voor het succes van en de steun voor de Europese Unie.

In deze module verkrijgen studenten kennis over de wordingsgeschiedenis, de organen en het functioneren van de Europese Unie. Daarbij wordt kaartkennis gecombineerd met verdieping door toepassing van bestuurskundige theoretische invalshoeken (o.a. over integratiemechanismen, multi-level governance en democratie-opvattingen). Daarnaast wordt aandacht besteed aan een vergelijkend perspectief. Studenten wordt vertrouwd gemaakt met vergelijking als onderzoeksmethode. Het object van vergelijking betreft de inhoud van beleid en de organisatie en het functioneren van beleidssectoren tussen verschillende Europese landen, bijvoorbeeld in het kader van de totstandkoming of uitvoering van Europees beleid. Studenten voeren in een groep een internationaal vergelijkend onderzoek uit en rapporteren daarover.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>Na afloop van deze module kan de student:

column2: • de politieke wordingsgeschiedenis van de Europese Unie weergeven en de onderliggende mechanismen uitleggen;
• de belangrijkste instituties van de Europese Unie en hun onderlinge verhouding beschrijven
• het proces van vorming en uitvoering Europees beleid weergeven en vanuit bestuurskundig optiek de sterktes en zwaktes daarvan aangeven
• een gefundeerd oordeel geven over het democratische gehalte van het de Europese Unie en over mogelijke verbetervoorstellen
• de huidige ontwikkelingen in historisch perspectief plaatsen en een beargumenteerd oordeel geven op de maatschappelijke en bestuurlijke implicaties daarvan.
• een weloverwogen keuze maken ten aanzien van de opzet en uitvoering van vergelijkend onderzoek tussen verschillende landen in Europees perspectief en een dergelijk onderzoek uitvoeren.
• reflecteren op verschillen en overeenkomsten in de organisatie en het functioneren van beleidssectoren in verschillende landen

MLF van Minnen', 'mr. MN Kuijer', 'mr.dr. E van Vliet', 'mr.drs. JR Vos', 'prof.mr.dr. JH Even']",,"Inhoud

column1: <body>De doorwerking van het internationale recht op het Nederlandse arbeidsrechtelijke rechtssysteem zal worden besproken. Daarnaast maakt met name het Europees recht het relatief eenvoudig dat een werknemer vanuit Nederland elders in de EU te werk wordt gesteld en vice versa. De regels die hierbij gelden en de problemen die hierdoor kunnen ontstaan worden besproken. Vraagstukken die worden behandeld zijn onder meer: welke fundamentele vrijheden staan de werkgever en de werknemer ter beschikking, hoe verhouden deze vrijheden zich met arbeidsrechtelijke beginselen en rechten, welk recht is van toepassing op de internationale arbeidsovereenkomst en welke rechter is bevoegd bij een geschil. Naast deze meer individuele vraagstukken wordt ook ingegaan op de rol en de rechten van de (Europese) sociale partners binnen de Europese sociale dialoog.</body>

column2: <title></title>
<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>
• De student kan de invloed en doorwerking van Europees en internationaal (sociaal verzekerings)recht in het Nederlandse arbeidsrecht toepassen op een concrete casus.
• De student kan beoordelen welke rechter in een internationaal arbeidsgeschil bevoegd is en welk recht van toepassing is.
• De student kan beoordelen wanneer sprake is van internationale detachering, wat de gevolgen daarvan zijn en welke beperkingen wel en niet kunnen worden opgelegd aan internationale dienstverleners.

• De student kan de wijze waarop Europese vrijheden doorwerken in een concrete casus beoordelen en identificeren hoe en waar zich spanningen voordoen tussen deze vrijheden en het (nationale) arbeidsrecht.
• De student kan de ontwikkelingen in de Europese en internationale context schetsen en vanuit die context ontwikkelingen beoordelen.
• De student kan beoordelen en beargumenteren onder welke voorwaarden een beroep op de Wmo 2015 kan worden gedaan en op welke voorzieningen aanspraak kan worden gemaakt.

• De student kan reflecteren op, en een beargumenteerd standpunt innemen ten aanzien van, de voorgeschreven literatuur en ten aanzien van vraagstukken met betrekking tot de voorgeschreven bijzondere arbeidsverhouding(en).

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/89221,2019,Evaluation of Development Policy, Programmes and Projects",Engels,International Institute of Social Studies (ISS),,"['dr. BA Demena', 'dr. M Faling', 'dr. N van Stapele', 'dr. S Gyamfi Afrifa']",,

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Evolution is such a crucial discipline of modern biology that, in 1973, evolutionary biologist Theodosius Dobzhansky wrote: ""nothing in biology makes sense except in the light of evolution"". In this course, a comprehensive introduction to the fascination field of evolutionary biology will be presented. Topics that will be covered include: the origin of abiotic and cellular life, the theory of evolution by natural selection (descent with modification), concepts of fitness and adaptation, the genetic and developmental basis of evolutionary change, micro- and macroevolution, speciation and extinction, elementary population genetics, palaeontology, and human evolution.

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>

column3: After completing this course, you will have a basic knowledge of:

column5: the theory of evolution by natural selection (descent with modification);
the concepts of fitness and adaptation;
the genetic and developmental basis of evolutionary change;
the origin of abiotic and cellular life;
micro- and macroevolution;
speciation and extinction;
population genetics;
palaeontology;
human evolution.

column2: </body>
