https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/87570,2019,Global supply chain management,Engels,"Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,"['dr. M Pourakbar', 'dr. M Stevens', 'prof.dr.ir. MBM de Koster']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Supply chain management (SCM) has emerged as one of the major areas for companies to gain a competitive edge. Managing supply chains is a complex and challenging task, due to the current business trends of expanding product variety, short product life cycles, increasing outsourcing, globalization of business, and continuous advances in information technology. What is more, supply chain management, as a natural successor to operations management, is a fundamental driver not only for further improving operations but also for strengthening the competitive position. When a company faces the pressure of excessive inventories, degraded customer service, escalating costs and declining profits, or a poor return on assets, its supply chain is out of control. On the other hand, when a company moves into new markets or new technologies, it must have its supply chain prepared for new business challenges and opportunities. The course will introduce students to concepts and techniques related to the design, management and improvement of supply chains, supply chain operations, and suppliers.

The course focuses on a variety of challenging supply chain business situations. For example, how operations and alignment with suppliers and customers can be used to design winning companies, how the benefits of information sharing can be estimated in the context of supply chain, and what supply chain strategies match with proliferating product variety. Other topics include, but are not limited to, supply chain design, performance measurement and metrics, inter-organizational collaboration, global sourcing, business process integration, and alignment of incentives.

This is (in part) a discussion-based course that makes use of the so-called case teaching method. Case studies as well as pedagogical games are used to set up a platform for discussion in the classroom. The format relies heavily on the capability of students to think critically and their readiness to be engaged in discussions that include both problem solving and decision-making. Hence, students are expected to be prepared for the scheduled sessions according to the detailed syllabus that will be distributed at the beginning of the course. Lecturing is used for teaching some supply chain management concepts and tools, since we aim to maximize the benefit of the course from the perspective of students. We also deploy operations and supply chain games (physical and computerized) to create a sense of urgency and understanding in how to solve problems at hand. The textbook is meant to supplement the collection of journal articles, cases and other materials distributed in class. The written exam will be designed so that it tests how well the student can apply concepts, methods and tools learnt during the course.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>At this end of this course, students should:

column2: • be able to evaluate opportunities and challenges related to the operations and supply chain strategy of companies in (inter)national contexts;
• be able to analyze performance-related business problems and design and propose solutions;
• be able to find relevant literature and apply this to a business case;
• be able to understand quantitative and apply qualitative techniques to analyze and interpret research findings;
• be able to create feasible plans of action and develop sensible decisions on how to deal with a particular supply chain challenge;
• have knowledge of, and skills for, collaborating, managing and coordinating operations in diverse teams and in complex demand-supply networks;
• be able to defend problem formulations and solutions based on sound arguments; and
• be able to critically think about problem definitions and to reflect on solutions proposed by yourself and others.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/85518,2019,Globalisation & Society I,Engels,Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences,,['dr. M Parizek', 'prof.dr. M Onderco']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

‘Globalization I: Culture & Society’ intends to introduce the phenomenon of globalization, and how it affects modern societies. This course will give you an opportunity to explore how various facets of globalization impact the world we live in today.

This course starts with recognizing how globalization affects the world around us. We then continue with looking at how globalization influences social identities. What defines our identity, who are we? We will then turn to the social media, and the ways how they transform the world around us. Then, we continue by looking at migration as an essentially globalizing phenomenon. In addition to immaterial culture, globalization very fundamentally affects also material culture – and we will analyze this process. We close by looking at how globalization influences the men and women in the world.

By the end of the course, you will understand that all culture is deeply affected by globalization – beyond what you would expect when you first enter the classroom. But is it all rosy? Never too far from real world, the contents of this course will touch on most of the topics that animate the debates in 2018.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>This course offers an introduction to globalization, and how it affects modern societies. At the end of the course, you should be able to:

column2: • Identify what globalization is
• Identify and illustrate how globalization influences everyday life
• Compare various theoretical aspects of understanding globalization
• Contrast and evaluate various empirical ways to evaluate globalization’s impact on culture and society

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/85520,2019,Globalisation & Society II,Engels,Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences,,['dr. M Parizek', 'prof.dr. M Onderco']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
‘Globalization: Economy & Politics’ will give you an opportunity to explore how globalization impacts on local conditions, as well as how governments cope with the globalizations’ impact.

The course starts where the course ‘Globalization: Culture & Society’ left off. We begin with a discussion of economic globalization. Why do businesses move to countries with lower production costs, and with what consequences for all involved? We then continue with the discussion of poverty and inequality, drawing on both local cases and evidence from across the world. Does globalization make inequality increase, or does it help societies to cope with it?

Governments frequently try to manage the challenges through international cooperation. What have been the patterns and why is it so? What are the consequences for states, as well as for the international institutions? How do such institutions work?

By the end of the course, you will understand how the pressures on corporate boards in New York influence real livelihoods in Africa. You will be also able to explain why some international organizations adopt decisions in very clumsy way.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: <li>This course offers an introduction to globalization, and how it affects economic life in modern societies. At the end of the course, you should be able to:
<ul>

column3: • Evaluate the consequences of economic globalization the globalization backlash
• Explain the emergence and patterns of supranational governance

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/87071,2019,Globalisation and the Making of Europe, 1850-present",Engels,"Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,['dr. JJ Euwe'],,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>After an introduction on trade before the industrial revolution, the relation between increased specialisation, industrialisation and the growth of economic contacts will be discussed. In the second half of the 19th century, monetary stability and free trade created a truly global economy, but not without suppressing a substantial part of the  world. From 1914 on, two world wars and the Cold War prevented a complete recovery of economic relations. Political interests caused that national economies were created with relatively limited international contacts. In post-1945 Europe this was a problem. Not only had the 1930s shown that economic nationalism was fatal for growth and development, but Germany also was a problem. For these reasons European economic integration seemed a solution. Until the collapse of the Soviet Union, this proved very successful. In the 1990s liberalisation of international markets, but also, just as in the late 19th century, an enormous decline of transport costs, caused a second period of globalisation. Now multinational companies cut apart their production chains,  and each step was done wherever in the world is cheapest. Europe was no longer the centre and its process of integration, that after the Cold War got a boost, is now even crumbling.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: • Students can explain the history and theory of international economic relations since the 19th century
• Students can explain how developments in Europe’s political economy since the 19th century are related to globalization
• Students are able to assess Europe’s political-economical position in the world

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/88000,2019,Globalisation, Digitalisation and Crime",Engels,Erasmus School of Law,,"['dr. W van der Wagen, MSc', 'prof.dr. R van Swaaningen']",,"Inhoud

column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: The course starts with two general lectures on the question why we should be engaged with international and comparative research in criminology; how with the process of globalisation a so-called ‘global criminology’ has emerged; and point at some socio-historical and cultural factors that have determined why criminology developed differently in Europe, North America, Latin America and Africa. The key-question in this respect is whether concrete criminological questions can actually be addressed with theoretical models that pretend to have a global validity, but mostly have Western biases. Next we will follow the structure of Katja Franko her book, of which the central line is that globalisation and digitalization offers opportunities for certain people and indeed confronts others with new limitations and forms of social exclusion.  Globalisation and digitalisation also come along with types of crime and deviance that take place across physical and digital borders. In this context, we deal with human trafficking, cybercrime, eco-crime and crimes against humanity. Additional readings offer a more concrete analysis of each of these issues, whereas guest-lecturers and practitioners will bridge the academic and the practical dimensions of the issues discussed.

column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: <body>This course aims to give insight in the cultural embeddedness of criminological perspectives and research traditions; the different ways we do international and cross-cultural research in criminology in the global and digital age; the different themes in global criminology; and indeed the different positions that are taken in these fields.</body>
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/86961,2019,Globalisation, culture and place",Engels,"Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,['dr. TA Calkins III'],,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

In this course, we will discuss theories and empirical cases related to the contemporary functioning of art worlds and the dynamics of cultural globalisation and aesthetic appropriation which shape them. Arguably, cultural production and consumption have become more transnationally-oriented. We look at the changing relationship between cultural production and consumption and place; the networked nature of artistic production and consumption, and the social conventions that govern them. Students get acquainted with the major contemporary trends and developments in the visual arts, music and the media, drawing on case studies from Western and non-Western context.  This course will be conducted as seminar which foregrounds student discussion and analysis of the readings.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>This course aims to take a fresh look at the notion of art worlds and the socialized nature of artistic and cultural production and consumption à la Becker, in light of theories of and empirical research on cultural globalisation. Drawing on examples from contemporary art movements, the media and music industries from around the world, we look at how art worlds operate across spatial scales; and how trends and social conventions spread across the world; and how they become embedded in different places and social contexts.</body>

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/99515,2019,Globalization and Global Governance,Nederlands,International Institute of Social Studies (ISS),,[],,
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/87198,2019,Globalization and Media Industries,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,['dr. AFM Krijnen'],,"Inhoud

column2: <title></title>
<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: Central to the seminar is cultural globalization: the global dispersion of (popular) cultural products. Cultural exchange transcending regions and nation-states is not a new phenomenon, but the past three decades witnessed an accelerated intensification of international cultural flows, thanks to much improved dissemination means (e.g. streaming and other digital technologies) and  transnationalisation in media and cultural-industry businesses.

Media are pivotal in this process of cultural globalization: all around the world, people are familiar with TV series such as The Big Bang Theory, the Marvel Cinematic Universe and popular music artists like Beyoncé. Globalization however, is not the same as Americanization: Indian movies, South Korean popular culture (K-wave) and formats such as The Voice are sold and consumed all over the world. In this course the meanings of developments in the media industries for production, content and consumption of media products is scrutinized. Due to their global presence entertainment genres form the focal point of this course. To critically examine cultural globalization in relation to media industries and the symbolic meanings produced the ‘critical political economy’ approach is adopted.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: • Key developments in the global spread of culture and the role of media therein.
• Different perspectives in the scholarly and public debate on the nature and impact of cultural globalization.
• Apply relevant theoretical insights and methods in the analysis of globalization processes and their social consequences.
• Critically reflect on academic texts, both verbal and in written form.
• Design and write an essay; make an academic argument.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/87858,2019,Globalization and Multidimensional Legal Orders,Engels,Erasmus School of Law,,['dr. F Coman Kund', 'dr. F Violi', 'dr. M van der Sluis', 'N Tilahun']",,"Inhoud

column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: During this course students will explore the multidimensional nature of the legal orders (a new development) that lawyers are confronted with in a globalized world. The focus will be on how various above-national legal orders, such as the international and European Union legal orders but also international private legal orders (think e.g. of the Forest Stewardship Council wood certification scheme), inter-relate and how they relate to the values enshrined in national legal orders. The point of departure for the course will be how the internationalization and Europeanization of law relate to enhanced economic integration and interdependence and may compromise values that are regarded as essential to law as developed in liberal legal orders. Relevant values include those related to the rule of law, democracy and human rights. In other words, during the course legal developments related to enhanced economic interdependence, often resulting in technocratic decision-making at international and European levels of decision making, will be problematized in an interdisciplinary context. The course builds on the knowledge, insights and skills acquired during the course Research and Writing Skills in European Union and International Law and in particular seeks to broaden the students’ knowledge of the processes of economic integration and enhance his/her research, analytical and presentation skills.

The course is problem-based, in the sense that real-world issues, rather than doctrinal approaches to law, are the point of departure. Even if, in considering these issues students will become familiar with concepts that are essential components of the systems of international and European Union law. These systemic approaches will be further explored in the courses Foundations of European Economic Integration and Foundations of Global Governance, taught in block three. In block three, students chose one of these two courses, depending on whether they wish to further specialize in European Union or international law.</body>

column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: <body>The learning objectives of the Research and Writing Skills course apply equally to the present course. In addition, after successful completion of the course, a student will be able to independently:

column2: •     Engage in  legal comparison, that is comparing legal developments at the level of the European Union and international level to each other and to legal values associated with national legal orders, and thus engage in vertical legal analysis (learning objective 2);

•     Analyze and assess the consequences of a multidimensional legal order, integrating the findings of other disciplines, in particular political science, sociology and economics, into the analysis and assessment (learning objectives 3 and 5); and
•     Develop legal advice on pertinent legal problems (objective 6) taking into account ethical considerations (learning objective 10).

column1: In addition, participants will continue to practice presenting their work to others during the workshops (objective 11) and will start to identify new developments in international and European Union law (objective 12).
